Gas sorption properties

As discussed above, the frameworks 1 and 2 are stable up to 340\u00b0C, thus gas adsorption property of the complexes can be expected. Before gas adsorption tests, activation to remove the guest molecules from the pores by heating under vacuum is a required pretreatment and the as-synthesized crystal samples were heated at an optimized temperature of 140\u00b0C for 20h. To verify whether the framework of 1 can be sustained after the removal of the solvent molecules, PXRD patterns were measured (). The framework of 1 still has crystallinity after removing the solvent molecules, but the PXRD pattern of the activated sample is different from the as-synthesized one which may be attributed to the framework dynamics of 1. The crystalline solid of 1 can be re-generated by immersing the activated sample in 10mL DMF for 12h as indicated by the PXRD measurements () . The results show that the host framework of complex 1 is flexible enough to change its structure depending on the nature of the guest molecules, and the framework transformations are reversible. While complex 2 shows good crystallinity after removing the guest water molecules and the PXRD pattern of the activated sample shifts and becomes broad compared with the as-synthesized one (), therefore, the gas sorption isotherms of 1 and 2 are investigated. The N2 adsorption isotherms for 1 and 2 are shown in \na and b, it can be seen that no N2 uptake was observed at 77K for 1 and 2, hysteresis was observed between the adsorption and desorption curves down to the lowest attainable pressure, which are characteristic for type-H3 sorption . However, significant amounts of CO2 (195K) were adsorbed (c) and both isotherms present typical type-I curves , which is the characteristic of microporous material. The amounts of adsorbed CO2 increase abruptly at the beginning and reach to 60.90cm3 (STP)/g (1.40mmol/g) at 1.0 atom for 1, 43.19cm3 (STP)/g (0.82mmol/g) for 2, approximately 0.48 CO2 and 0.23 CO2 molecules per formula unit were adsorbed for 1 and 2. Fitting the BET equations to the CO2 adsorption isotherm gave estimated surface areas of 119 and 68m2/g for complexes 1 and 2, respectively. The gas sorption isotherms show distinct hysteresis between the adsorption\u2013desorption curves, which must be attributed to the intercrystalline voids . It is noteworthy that no N2 were adsorbed in spite of the channel size larger than the kinetic diameter of N2 (3.64\u00c5), thus, the selective sorption behaviors of CO2 over N2 are attributed to the significant quadrupole moment of CO2 (\u22121.4\u00d710\u221239\nCm2), which induces specific interactions with the host framework . Considering the great current interest of CO2 adsorption/separation, the present work provides nice example of selective sorption behaviors of CO2 over N2 that is not size-controlled, but quadrupole moment induced .

Significantly, the assembly of paddle-wheel clusters as rigid SBUs with polytopic carboxylate linkers could generate rigid porous frameworks with permanent porosity and open functionalized metal sites . As a consequence, Cu2(COO)4 paddle-wheel subunits for different orientations act as square SBUs linking 1D chains to provide a 3D framework with regular 1D parallelogram nanosized channels along the a axis (grid dimensions of 10.55×9.42Å2, calculated from the neighboring Cu(II) atoms) (c). Furthermore, two different kinds of square apertures are present. The first one is polar owing to the effective pore surface occupied mainly by uncoordinate carboxylate oxygen atoms and coordinate aqua molecules, and the twisted benzenyl groups of bptca4
− take up the second hydrophobic channels. When seen from a

×

b plane, the framework structure of 1 is closely compact (), and thus, show noninterpenetrating single network, which depends on the asymmetrical nature of the bptca4
− molecules possessing long molecular backbone to stretch space and large metal clusters laterally to block the interpenetrating aisles. A calculation using platon revealed that the potential total solvent-accessible void space of the framework is 1072.2Å3, corresponding to the 43.5% of the unit cell volume 2466.1Å3
. From the view of topology, the SBUs of dimer [Cu2O2] subunit and tetranuclear [Cu4(μ
3-OH)2] cluster serve as 4-connected and 8-connected nodes, respectively. The bptca4
− ligands show two kinds of coordinated modes, but both of them link four copper-based SBUs, and thus, the organic ligands act as 4-connected nodes. So, the whole 3D framework adopts an unusual tetranodal (4,4,4,8)-connected net with the point symbol of {412.812.104}{43.83}4{46}{86} (d).

Two adjacent Cu1 ions are linked by four bidentate bridging carboxylate groups to afford a paddle-wheel Cu2(COO)4 subunit with the Cu–Cu distance of 2.6391(18)Å, being shorter than that of complex 1 (b). Due to the different coordination environment of Cu atoms, the respective paddle-wheel units in 1 and 2, also display some differences, which each bptca4
− ligand of 1 connects only one paddle-wheel cluster and the cation of 2 does two paddle-wheel clusters. The Cu2(COO)4 fragment gets ulteriorly incorporation with four neighboring paddle-wheel clusters via two bidentate bridging carboxylate groups of isophthalate to give a single Cu2(COO)4 paddle-wheel supporting grid structure. These 2D layers are linked in the third direction by folded mononuclear Cu(bptc)2 units, to form a 3D nanoporous framework (c). Similar to 1, the framework accommodates infinite open 1D quadrate channels with 11.20Å caliber (Cu…Cu distance). Meanwhile, the closely arrangement of the components on the a

×

b or a

×

c plane suggests the noninterpenetrating features of the final framework (). The potential solvent-accessible volume of 2 is 2129.5Å3, which corresponds to 42.7% of unit cell volume 4991.0Å3 according to the platon calculations . From the viewpoint of the network topology, 2 possesses 3D (4,4)-connected binodal frameworks with {42.84} PtS-type topology, by considering each mononuclear Cu(bptca)2 and paddle-wheel Cu2(COO)4 clusters as 4-connected nodes (d).

Complexes 1 and 2 are air-stable and can retain the crystalline integrity at ambient conditions. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) show that 1 and 2 have onset weight losses within the temperature range of 125\u2013240\u00b0C and 110\u2013205\u00b0C, respectively (\n). The first steps of TGA curves correspond to the release of the unknown disordered solvent molecules. Almost without pause, the host MOFs begin to decompose continuously until the final products CuO obtained. Consequently, the final MOFs exhibit ordinary thermal stability, which can be attributed to the anion nature of the frameworks strengthened by charge-balancing guest cations.

In this work, the rod-like ligand 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-yl)-benzene (bib) has been utilized as a building block to perform counterion researches on the structural diversities of coordination polymers. A series of new manganese compounds, {[Mn(bib)3(ClO4)2](CHCl3)2}
n
 (1), [Mn(bib)2(N3)2]
n
 (2), [Mn(bib)2(HCO2)2]
n
 (3), [Mn(bib)2(Ac)2]
n
 (4), {[Mn(bib)2(CF3SO3)2](CH2Cl2)4}
n
 (5), and [Mn(bib)2(SO4)]
n
 (6) have been successfully synthesized. Compound 1 shows a 3D interpenetrating α-Po network only based on the bib linker. Compounds 2 and 3 exhibit a 2D (4,4) layer with parallel and incline interpenetration, respectively. Compounds 4 and 5 display a parallel-packing 2D (4,4) layer with the porosity of 23.4% and 61.4%, respectively. Compound 6 furnishes a 3D α-Po framework with a 2D (4,4) layer pillared by the μ2-SO4
2− ion. The structural diversities among 1–6 have been carefully discussed, and the roles of counterions (from coordination affinity and molecular size) in the self-assembly of coordination polymers have also been well documented. Furthermore, magnetic properties of 6 have been carefully studied.

Results and discussion

Description of crystal structures

{[Mn(bib)3(ClO4)2](CHCl3)2}\n\u221e\n (1)

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that compound 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/n, and the MnII ion locates at the inversion center. As show in \na, the MnII ion lies in a distorted octahedral coordination environment, which is surrounded by six imidazole rings of distinct bib ligands. The lengths of equatorial bonds are 2.258(5)\u00c5, with an elongation to 2.307(5)\u00c5 for axial bonds, which are all in good agreement with those typically observed () .

As exhibited by the infinite double-stranded helix, the most fascinating structural feature of 1 is that the architecture is composed of two equivalent frameworks. Topological analysis suggests that these two independent frameworks are interlocked with each other to give an interpenetrating \u03b1-Po network (\na) . As a consequence, the overall void volume after interpenetration is about 907.4\u00c53, i.e. 38.3% of the cell volume using the PLATON program . Unfortunately, the void space in the aperture is occupied by the ClO4\n\u2212 counterion and chloroform molecule (b).

The bib ligand takes a bidentate mode to bridges the 4-connected MnII ion to finally form a 2D (4,4) layer if the bib ligand is simplified as a linear linker (b). These 2D (4,4) layers are piled up together in a parallel pattern to exhibit a 1D parallelogram channel with the dimensions of approximately 10.2\u00d712.4\u00c52 along the a axis (). The 3D packing architecture shows large void space of about 711.5\u00c53, i.e. 61.4% of the cell volume using the PLATON program. However, the available void space is greatly reduced by the CF3SO3\n\u2212 counterion, which locates in the 1D channel (\na). Interestingly, the overall void volume of the neutral supermolecular framework is still up to about 478.4\u00c53, i.e. 41.3% of the cell volume, which is filled with the dichloromethane molecule (b). Unfortunately, when the as-synthesized crystals were taken out from the solution, and placed in the air at room temperature for about 1h, the original shape was destroyed and large crystals gradually collapsed into a mass of powder. The XRPD reveals that the collapsed powder was not matched with the crystal sample (). Furthermore, the collapsed powder exhibits no gas adsorption for N2. Thus crystals of 5 may convert into another tight coordination polymer in the air, which is failed to be characterized by the X-ray crystallography although trying our best.

For compounds 2–5, there is a great character in common that the counterion (N3
−, HCO2
−, Ac− or CF3SO3
−) takes a monodentate mode to bind with the MnII ion on the axial site. Other four equatorial sites are coordinated by the bib ligand, and the bidentate ligand connects the metal center into a 2D (4,4) layer. Nevertheless, compounds 2–5 exhibit quite a number of differences among the topological structure. In 2, the large window of one (4,4) layer is pierced by the bib ligand from another (4,4) layer, and such two identical 2D sheets are interlocked with each other to form parallel interpenetration. For 3, quadrangular grids of one 2D layer are pierced by the bib ligand from different symmetry-equivalent 2D layers. That is to say, each 2D layer of 3 is interlocked with infinite parallel layers to form incline interpenetration. However, with regard to 4 and 5, the 2D (4,4) layer has no entanglement, and is arranged in a parallel pattern to present 1D parallelogram channels with the dimensions of approximately 6.0×6.0 and 10.2×12.4Å2, respectively. The counterions of 4 and 5, Ac− and CF3SO3
−, are larger than three-atom ions in 2 and 3 (N3
− and HCO2
−). Thus compounds 4 and 5 have a bulkier metal coordination sphere bound with two counterions, which hinders the happening of entanglement . Furthermore, the volume of CF3SO3
− ion is bigger than that of Ac− ion, which makes that compound 5 has an even larger 1D channel supported by the counterion. The 3D packing architecture of 5 shows void space of about 711.5Å3, i.e. 61.4% of the cell volume, also larger than corresponding values of 4 (315.6 and 23.4%).

Magnetic properties of compound 6


Magnetic data were collected by using crushed crystals of 6, which is confirmed the phase purity by a comparison between the experimental and simulated XRPD patterns (). The magnetic susceptibility (χ
M) was measured under 1kOe in the range of 2–300K (
). The χ
M
T value per MnII ion at 300K is about 4.57cm3
Kmol−1, in agreement with the spin-only value for an isolated MnII ion with S=5/2 and g=2.0 (4.38cm3
Kmol−1). As the temperature lowered, the χ
M
T product decreases slowly in the high-temperature range, and decrease more rapidly blow 50K. The decrease of χ
M
T clearly indicates the antiferromagnetic (AFM) coupling interaction between metal centers. The data follow the Curie–Weiss law with C=4.69cm3
Kmol−1 and θ=−2.63K. The negative θ value also indicates the AFM coupling between metal ions, and C value is as expected for the MnII system .

The reaction of L with two equivalents of silver nitrate in a CH2Cl2–MeCN solution afforded after slow evaporation colorless crystals of 1 in high yield, that are suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis. Elemental analysis data reveals an empirical formula of Ag(L)NO3, suggesting a 1:1 metal-to-ligand ratio in 1. 1 is poorly soluble in common solvents, and slightly soluble in dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO). The 1HH NMR spectrum of 1 in DMSO-d
6 reveals only signals identical to those of the free ligand, indicating the decomposition of the complex in DMSO. In the IR spectrum of 1 a strong band at around 1405cm−1 appeared due to the coordinated NO3
− ions. X-ray structural analysis confirmed the formation of a coordination network involving effective Ag–S binding in the solid state (
). 1 crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group Cmc21 and in the asymmetric unit there contains only one half of ligand L, one silver ion and nitrate anion, and the second half of L was generated by symmetry (operation code: −x, y, z). The Flack parameter of crystal 1 having a acentric space group was refined to be −0.01(2), indicating 1 crystallizes as an enantiopure form, although achiral ligand was used. It was noticed that as seen in a the ligand molecules in 1 adopt the conformation I and type-A binding mode with two silver(I) centers related by a C
2 symmetric axis (). Relevant bond parameters around metal centers are summarized in 
. The silver(I) center is tetracoordinate with two sulfur atoms from symmetry-related ligands and two oxygen atoms of the bridging nitrate ions, being in a slightly distorted tetrahedral environment. The Ag-S bond distances are almost identical (2.5185(6) and 2.5186(6)Å, respectively), falling in the range of Ag–S bond lengths reported in the literature , yet the Ag–O bonds are slightly different in length (2.357(3) and 2.533(3)Å). Propagation of the repeat structure unit along the silver(II) centers results in the formation of an infinite 2-D coordination network which is composed of 20-membered macrocycles containing two ligand units, two silver(I) centers and two bridging nitrato-O atoms (b and c). In each macrocycle, the Ag⋯Ag nonbonding distance between two silver(I) centers bonded to the same ligand is approximately 10.7Å, while the O-bridged Ag⋯Ag nonbonding distance is approximately 4.6Å. The two phenyl rings of ligands in the macrocycle are arranged in an edge-to-face fashion and thus effective C–H⋯π interaction is observed between the rings. The C–H⋯ π (centroid) distance as illustrated in c is as short as ca. 2.85Å (c). It is worth mentioning that previously a silver(I) perchlorate complex based on a similar thioether ligand, 1,3-bis(phenylthiomethyl)benzene has been reported, where a structurally related grid-like network was observed . However, the structure of the repeating macrocyclic motif in this network is essentially distinct with that of 1. In the structure reported previously , the silver centers are bridged by two oxygen atoms of the perchlorate anion, and the Ag–O bond distances are relatively longer (2.556(10) and 2.719(4)Å, respectively), indicating weaker bonding interactions. In addition, the phenyl rings in the macrocycle are arranged in a face-to-face mode by π⋯π stacking interaction (the distance between two aromatic planes is ca. 3.5Å), in sharp contrast to the C–H⋯π interactions found in 1 (c)

Synthesis and characterization of Ag2(L)(BF4)2·0.25(H2O) (2)

The critical role played by the counter anion (nitrate ion) in bridging the silver(I) center to form the 2-D network in 1 encouraged us to investigate the impact of other silver salts on the self-assembly process. We next examined the reaction between L and silver tetrafluoroborate under the same conditions as for 1, and colorless crystals of 2 were obtained in moderate yield. IR spectrum of 2 shows strong absorption as a broad band at around 3565cm−1, indicating the presence of water molecules. In addition, peaks appear at ca. 1028 and 519cm−1, consistent with the inclusion of BF4
− in the coordination compound. X-ray structural analysis identifies the main silver(I) network in the solid state, although several disorders were found (see Section  for details). 2 crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group Imma and the asymmetric unit contains only one half of the ligand molecule. Unlike the case in 1, two independent silver(I) centers that bind to the same sulfur atom through a μ2-S bridging coordination are observed in the asymmetric unit of 2 (
a). The silver binding mode resembles the type-C mode in , whereas the ligand belongs to the conformation II (). Ag1 is two-coordinate with two symmetry-related sulfur atoms from distinct ligands and adopts an almost linear geometry (the S–Ag1–S angle is 172.12(4)°). In contrast, Ag2 is tetra-coordinate with not only two symmetry-related sulfur atoms, but also oxygen atoms from two water molecules that were involved in the structure of 2 during the reaction through a bis-μ2-O bridging mode. The counter anions BF4
− that are, as expected, non-coordinated exist in the lattice. Thus, the coordination chemistry and the extended supramolecular structure in 2 are completely different from that in 1, highlighting the drastic influence of counter anions.

Synthesis and characterization of Ag(L)2(PF6) (3)

Having disclosed the remarkable role the anions played in driving diverse supramolecular architectures, we further explored the anion effect on the Ag–L coordination chemistry, and used a larger anion hexafluorophosphate (PF6
−) for the reaction. Thus, the combination of L with 2.0equiv. AgPF6 under the same conditions for 1 and 2 afforded colorless crystals of 3 that were characterized by IR, elemental analysis and X-ray crystallography. Elemental analysis of the bulk sample reveals a metal-to-ligand ratio of 1:2, apparently different from those of 1 and 2, indicating new coordination chemistry in crystals of 3. The presence of PF6
− ion in the structure of 3 was confirmed by its IR spectrum showing characteristic stretching and bending at ca. 839 and 556cm−1. Indeed, X-ray structural analysis confirmed the formation of a novel 2-D network structure in 3 (
). 3 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/n and in the asymmetric unit two independent ligand molecules are observed. In addition, one silver(I) center and one PF6
− ion are present (a). Interestingly, in 3 the silver(I) center adopts a S4 coordination environment with a pseudo-tetrahedral geometry, different from that observed in 1 and 2. Each silver(I) ion is ligated via four sulfur donors from four distinct ligands and meanwhile each ligand binds to two silver(I) ions to form an infinite 2-D grid-like structure that constitutes of square 4+4 metallomacrocycles (b and c). Two ligand molecules in the macrocycle of 3 adopt the same conformation I as shown in  and the metal binding belongs to the type-A pattern (). The 4+4 grid has a dimension of ca. 9.5×9.6Å2, and features a saddle-like shape. The two pairs of Ag⋯Ag distances between two Ag(I) centers in the grid are 9.513 and 9.647Å, respectively, and the four Ag(I) centers are well coplanar. One PF6
− ion resides in the center of each saddle-shaped grid. Ag–S bond lengths in 3 are close to those in 1. Bond expansion along the four Ag(I) centers of the grid leads to the assembly of a 2-D cationic network running down the ab direction, as shown in c. Again, the anion PF6
−, albeit non-coordinated, has governed the coordination and supramolecular assembly between silver(I) and L, and is completely responsible for the generation of the 2-D grid-like network in 3, in sharp contrast to the structures of 1 and 2.

Synthesis and characterization of Ag(L)(SbF6)(NCCH3)2 (4)

Encouraged by the above findings of remarkable anion induction effect, finally, we studied the reaction by replacing PF6
− with its analog, a larger anion, hexafluoroantimonate (SbF6
−). Accordingly, the same reaction conditions were applied and suitable crystals of 4 were obtained from the reaction of L with AgSbF6. The incorporation of acetonitrile molecules in the structure of 4 was confirmed by the IR absorption at around 2290cm−1 and the strong peak at 556cm−1 indicates the presence of SbF6
− ions. Elemental analysis of bulk sample of 4 also suggests a 1:1 metal–ligand ratio. X-ray crystallographic studies reveal a 1-D polymeric chain, distinct from all the above described structures. 4 crystallizes in the orthorhombic system with a P212121 space group. Unlike 1, the structure of 4 was refined with a Flack parameter of 0.48(2), indicating a racemic twin existing in the cell of the crystal. The asymmetric unit contains one independent ligand, one Ag+ (accompanied ion with one SbF6
−), and two coordinated CH3CN molecules (
a). Each Ag(I) is tetra-coordinate with two sulfur donors from two distinct ligands, and two nitrogen atoms from two CH3CN solvent molecules. Each ligand also coordinates with two symmetry-related Ag(I) centers. The Ag-S bond lengths are unexceptional to those in 1–3, while the S–Ag–S angle is 135.73(3)° and N–Ag–N angle is 90.96(15)°, severely deviated from a tetrahedral silver coordination sphere. The ligand molecule features the conformation II and the Ag-L binding is consistent with type-A coordination mode (). Extension of the repeating structural unit along the crystallographic a axis results in the observation of an infinite 1-D polymeric chain (b), which is distinct with the 2- or 3-D networks as discussed above for 1–3. Interestingly, chains propagate along the crystallographic a axis to form a helical structure and both the P- and M-helix were observed. This is consistent with the fact that the complex crystallizes as a racemic mixture. The pitch of helix is approximately 7.87Å, corresponding to the adjacent Ag⋯Ag separation in the chain. Compared to 3, although similar anions were used, the lower dimensionality of 4 should be attributed to the coordination of solvent molecules (CH3CN) with silver(I), which prevents other ligands from accessing the silver(I) spheres and limits further dimensional expansion.

Thermal properties

Thermal stability of four silver(I) coordination compounds were examined by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) under N2 atmosphere. The corresponding TG curves for 1\u20134 are presented in \n. As shown in , compound 1 is stable up to 179\u00b0C and then experiences decomposition in two stages (179\u2013365\u00b0C and 500\u2013645\u00b0C) with a total weight loss of ca. 54.8%, owing to the removal of ligand molecules from the complex (calcd. 54.0%). Compound 2 undergoes a small weight loss (ca. 4.2%) between 50 and 147\u00b0C, accounting for the loss of water molecules from the 3D silver framework of 2 (ca. 1.5 H2O per unit, calcd. 4.4%), which is in agreement with the data of elemental analysis, indicating 2 is hygroscopic in the air. 2 is then decomposed upon heating to 196\u00b0C by removing the ligand molecules. Compound 3 proves to be less thermostable and begins to decompose gradually from 163\u00b0C. In contrast, 4 is stable up to 212\u00b0C at which temperature a slight weight loss (ca. 1.25%) is observed, consistent with the removal of two coordinated CH3CN molecules per structural unit (calcd. 1.3%). Again, upon further heating major decomposition of 4 occurs at 234\u00b0C.

Graphical abstract

We report on the synthesis and crystal structures of two new zinc coordination polymers: [Zn2(oba)2(azpy)(dmf)2]\u00b76DMF (azpy=4,4\u2032-azopyridine) (3) and [Zn2(oba)2(bpe)]\u00b72DMF\u00b74H2O (bpe=\ntrans-1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethylene) (4). Compound 3 exhibits one-dimensional structure, and Compound 4 exhibits a three-dimensional structure that is interwoven by heteroorganic oba and bpe bridges. This structure, which is constructed by connected two-dimensional frameworks of [Zn2(oba)2] with bpe bridges, has a high porosity with a density of only 0.53gcm\u22123.

Abstract

We report on the synthesis and crystal structures of two new zinc coordination polymers with 4,4\u2032-oxybis(benzoate) (oba) ligands. Single crystals of [Zn2(oba)2(azpy)(dmf)2]\u00b76DMF(azpy=4,4\u2032-azopyridine) and [Zn2(oba)2(bpe)]\u00b72DMF\u00b74H2O (bpe=\ntrans-1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethylene) were prepared by treatment of Zn(CH3COO)2\n\u00b72H2O with the H2oba and bis-pyridine type ligands, azpy and bpe, respectively, in DMF. Compound [Zn2(oba)2(azpy)(dmf)2]\u00b76DMF has a unique ladder structure comprising of heteroorganic bridges, in which the Zn\u2013oba chains construct the side rails, while the Zn\u2013azpy\u2013Zn parts construct the rungs of the ladder framework. Despite the large size of the cavities, these ladder chains stack without interpenetration, and the cavities in the ladder framework are partially connected to create one-dimensional channel-like cavities. Compound [Zn2(oba)2(bpe)]\u00b72DMF\u00b74H2O exhibits a three-dimensional coordination framework that is comprised of heteroorganic bridges. The framework is interwoven by two-dimensional layers of [Zn2(oba)2] and the Zn2\u2013bpe chains. The three-dimensional framework, which contains large cavities, about 13\u00d711\u00c52 in area, has a high porosity and a density of only 0.53gcm\u22123.

The thermal stability of the highly porous framework of Compound 4 was estimated using thermogravimetric analysis (\n). The removal of the guest DMF molecules was observed below about 200\u00b0C (observed 18%, calcd 21%). Any ensuing weight loss due to deformation of the resulting dry sample was not observed until 310\u00b0C, implying a high stability of the guest-free framework of Compound 4. A similar stability was reported in the three-dimensional coordination polymer [M2(1,4-benzenedicarboxylate)L] (L=triethylenediamine, 4,4\u2032-bipyridine) , which has similar network motifs to Compound 4. Characterization of the functionalities based on the highly porous framework of Compound 4 is currently in progress.

Abstract

A lanthanide-organic framework constructed from a new \u03c0-electron rich ligand 5,5\u2032-(9H-carbazole-3,6-diyl)diisophthalic acid (H4L) and Tb(NO3)3\u00b76H2O, namely, [(CH3)2NH2][TbL] (1), has been synthesized under solvothermal condition. X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that complex 1 exhibits a 3D porous framework featuring a (4,8)-connected sqc net. The solid sample of 1 exhibits strong green fluorescence in the visible region upon excitation at 354nm. The fine grinding particles of 1 dispersed in ethanol shows good sensitivity for picric acid (PA), which can be reused at least five times for detecting PA. The good sensitivity and recyclability of 1 make it a potential fluorescent sensor for explosives detection.

Crystal structure description

Single-crystal X-ray analysis indicates that complex 1 crystallizes in the tetragonal crystal system with space group of I-42d. The asymmetrical unit of 1 contains half a Tb3+ ion, half a L4− ligand and the negative charge of the framework is balanced by half a (CH3)2NH2
+ cation, which was generated from the decomposed DMF. As shown in 
a, the central Tb3+ ion possesses an eight-coordinated square antiprism coordination mode, being linked to eight carboxylate oxygen atoms from six different L4− ligands. The Tb–O bond lengths vary from 2.260(5) to 2.501(5)Å, which are similar to those reported in other Tb3+ compounds . Two symmetry related Tb3+ ions are bridged by carboxylate groups to form a noteworthy paddle-wheel [Tb2(CO2)8] subunit with a Tb⋯Tb distance of 4.2938(17)Å. Each L4− anion coordinates to 8 Tb3+ ions, with carboxylate groups adopting two kinds of coordination modes: μ2-η1:η1 and μ1-η1:η1 mode. Finally, each binuclear [Tb2(CO2)8] subunit are linked by L4− anions to generate a fascinating 3D porous framework (b). The solvent-accessible volume in 1 is 2206.6Å3, equal to 36.6% of the volume of the unit cell calculated by the platon program. Topological analysis was carried out to get insight into the structure . As shown in c, the L4− anions and the [Tb2(CO2)8] subunits can be defined as 4- and 8-connected nodes, respectively. Therefore, complex 1 can be simplified as a (4,8)-connected sqc network with Schläfli symbol of (43
·63)(412
·616).

PXRD patterns and thermogravimetric analysis

The PXRD patterns of complex 1 are shown in . The peak positions of experimental PXRD patterns are in line with the simulated ones, showing the pure phase of the complex. As shown in , the TGA of 1 shows an initial gradual weight loss of 6.12% between 85\u00b0C and 242\u00b0C, corresponding to the release of (CH3)2NH2\n+ (Calc.: 6.62%). The compound 1 begins to decompose upon further heating and underwent a rapid weight loss of 64.58% from 242\u00b0C to 563\u00b0C, corresponding to the destruction of the H4L ligands.

Fluorescence behaviors and sensing properties

The lanthanide coordination polymers have displayed excellent fluorescence properties in the respect of their high color purity . So we investigated the ligand-assisted fluorescence properties of powder samples of the lanthanide complex at room temperature (). When excited at 354nm, complex 1 exhibits the characteristic emissions of Tb3+ ions in the visible region. The emission peaks at 490, 545, 585 and 621nm can be attributed to the transitions of 5D4–7F
J
 (J
=6, 5, 4, 3) from Tb3+ ions, respectively. Upon excitation at 243nm, the free H4L ligand exhibits a luminescent emission band at 388nm, which is attributed to the π–π∗ transition. The luminescent investigation on the complex 1 suggests that H4L ligand may sensitize the luminescence of Tb3+ ions. The strongest emission in 1 appears at 545nm which can be easily observed as bright green light by the naked eye. The remarkable fluorescence offers the possibility of 1 being a fluorescence sensor.

The sensing properties of 1 for NB prompted us to investigate its application in detecting different electron-withdrawing nitroaromatics. The nitroaromatics such as 4-nitrotoulene (4-NT), 2,4-dinitrotoluene (2,4-DNT), 4-ni-tro-chlorobenzene (4-NC), 2,4-dinitro-chlorobenzene (2,4-DNC), picric acid (PA) were added to a suspension of 1 (3mg) in ethanol (3mL). As shown in 
, upon the addition of the same amount of nitroaromatics ([nitroaromatics]=10ppm), different degrees of fluorescence quenching of the suspension were tested. The descending order of quenching efficiency was PA>4-NC>2,4-DNC>2,4-DNT>4-NT>NB. About quenching efficiency (QE=(1−
F/F
0)×100% (F
0 and F are the fluorescent intensities before and after the addition of nitroaromatics, respectively.)) of 76.9% for PA is observed, which is significantly more than that of 4-NC (29.2%), indicating that 1 shows a high selectivity for PA.

To further study the sensing capacity of 1 for PA, the emission spectra are monitored by gradually increasing PA contents of a suspension of 3mg of 1 dispersed in 3mL ethanol. The fluorescent intensity obviously decreased with the increasing PA concentration (\n). When the concentration of PA reached 30ppm, the quenching efficiency was 94.2% for 1, which is higher than or comparable to other MOF sensors, polymeric nanocomposites  and conjugated polymer sensors for PA. For example, the micrometer-sized MOF [Cd3(TPT)2(DMF)2]\u00b7(H2O)0.5 show an 82.5% quenching efficiency for PA . The quenching efficiency of the reported carbon and silver nanocomposites for PA is 99% . The fluorescence intensity of conjugated polymer flim only decreased with 77-fold fluorescence quenching . After immersing into the PA solution (1mM in ethanol) for 12h, crystals of 1 are collected by filtration, washed with EtOH and air-dried. Then the PXRD measurement was performed. The PXRD result indicates that the crystallinity of 1 was still remained after the experiment ().

Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) and Differential thermal gravity (DTG) for the H4L and the crystalline samples of compounds 1\u20133 were recorded under air atmosphere in the temperature range of 30\u2013700\u00b0C (\n, ). The TGA curves of all three compounds have released the lattice water before 350\u00b0C, reflecting the fact that the lattice water in the framework is unstable and easy to separate from framework at low temperatures. The first weight losses corresponding to the release of water molecules are observed before 365\u00b0C for compound 1 (observed 9.12%, calculated 7.83%), 323\u00b0C for compound 2 (observed 11.36%, calculated 13.69%), 325\u00b0C for compound 3 (observed 16.34%, calculated 13.84%). The anhydrous compositions begin to decompose at 365\u00b0C and ending above 490\u00b0C for 1, at 323\u00b0C and ending above 497\u00b0C for 2, and at 325\u00b0C and ending above 417\u00b0C for 3, due to the decomposition of the organic part of the framework. The remaining weight may correspond to the formation of ZnO for compound 1 (observed 18.14%, calculated 17.72%) and compound 2 (observed 20.12%, calculated 15.39%), CoO for compound 3 (observed 15.63%, calculated 14.42%).

UV\u2013vis absorption spectra of compound 1-3

The UV\u2013vis spectra of compound 1\u20133 together with the free H4L ligand in the solid state at room temperature were measured. The Kubelka-Munk functions  converted from the diffuse reflectance data were plotted in \n. The H4L exhibits strong absorption with a maximum at 316nm in the range of 280\u2212352nm, which probably corresponds to the \u03c0-\u03c0* and n-\u03c0* transitions centered on the benzene ring. The absorption of 4,4\u2032-bpy is strong in a similar range with one peak at 290nm . Compared to the free H4L ligand, compound 1\u20133 exhibit absorption with maxima at 307nm, 308nm, 305nm, respectively, and the absorption peaks of compounds 1, 2, and 3 have slightly blue-shifted in the same range. In compound 1, the absorption peak is more stronger than other compound at 280nm, which may be attributed to the effect of 4,4\u2032-bpy. In compound 3, the characteristic absorption bands of UV\u2013vis spectra around 580nm are correlated with the d-d transitions of tetrahedral coordinated Co2+\n.

Photoluminescence properties

The metal-organic frameworks are promising candidates for applicable photoluminescent materials such as chemical sensors, light emitting diodes, electro-chemical sensors and so on. Although a lot of transition metal ions and rare-earth ions have been used to construct MOFs, the Zn-based MOFs are the most interested transition metal based luminescent MOFs. The d10 metal ions not only have various coordination numbers and geometries, but also display luminescent properties with functional ligands . The photoluminescence properties of compound 1 and 2 together with the free H4L ligand, were investigated in the solid state at room temperature (\n) and depicted in \n, S4. The photoluminescent spectra of the free ligands show the main peak at 412nm (\u03bbex=339 ) for H4L, 466nm (\u03bbex=390nm) for 4,4\u2032-bpy , 436nm (\u03bbex=380nm) for bib , respectively, which may be caused by the \u03c0*-\u03c0 and \u03c0*-n transition. The emission spectra for bands were observed at 452nm (\u03bbex=337nm) for 1, 401 and 418nm (\u03bbex=348nm) for 2. As the literature reported, the d10 configured Zn(\u2161) cations are electrochemically inert, therefore, when coordinated by ligands, they cannot take an electron from the ligand with their 3d-orbitals, nor donate an electron to the ligand . In comparison to the free ligands, the emission maxima of 1 is red-shifted by 40nm as compared to free H4L ligand, and close to the free 4,4\u2032-bpy ligand, inferring their emission bands may be assigned to the intra-ligand charge transfer (ILCT), neither metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) nor ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) happened. The emission peaks of 2 are close to free H4L ligand, so the emission bands of 2 can probably be attributed to the intra-ligand charge transfer (ILCT). Experimental results show that compound 3 is non-emissive under similar conditions, indicating the emissions of organic ligands may be quenched completely in the compound, which may be due to the emission quencher of Co (\u2161) in the structure. In term of the structures and emission spectra of compound 1 and 2, it is inferred that different ligands co-ligands may be an important factor on influencing different luminescent properties of compounds .

Conclusions

In summary, we successfully designed and synthesized three coordination polymers based on flexible multicarboxylic acid 5,5\u2032-(butane-1,4-diyl)-bis(oxy)-diisophthalic acid (H4L), and one rigid ancillary bridging pyridine linkers 4,4\u2032 -bipyridine (4,4\u2032-bpy) for 1, one flexible ancillary imidazole linkers 1,4-bis (1H-imidazol-1-yl)-butane (bib) for 2 and 3. These compounds display interesting and versatile coordination features from 3D to 3D parallel entangled frameworks. Topological analysis reveals that 1\u20133 are 3D (4,4)-connected bbf topology net with the (64\u00b782)(66) topology. The adjustable channels size of individual 3D framework is realized by using different lengths of co-ligands from byp to bib with keeping similar architectures of compounds 1\u20133. In compound 3, the assignment of characteristic absorption bands of UV\u2013vis spectra at 580nm correlated with the d-d transitions of Co2+ ions in field of tetrahedral coordination is confirmed by the result of the single-crystal X-ray structure analysis. The solid-state photoluminescent properties of 1 and 2 were investigated, and the emission bands were assigned to the intra-ligand charge transfer (ILCT), and the different emission wavelength due to the effect of co-ligands. The solid-state thermal stabilities were investigated. The frameworks of 1, 2 and 3 are stable under 350\u00b0C.

To study the thermal behavior of compound 1, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) in N2 atmosphere with a heating rate of 10\u00b0Cmin\u22121 were performed on polycrystalline sample to determine its thermal behavior from 25 to 800\u00b0C. TGA on the as-synthesized sample of 1 indicated weight loss of 14.72% before 300\u00b0C, which corresponding to the release of solvent (DMF) molecules. The TGA curve of 1 indicates that the framework is stable up to ca. 300\u00b0C (Fig. S1). After that temperature, the framework begins to decompose. We notice that the compound 1 has less thermal stability than that of [Mn3(HCOO)6]\u00b7[1,4-dioxane] reported by Kim et al. . We also check the PXRD patterns between the desolvated and as-synthesized samples, and find that the main peaks of the desolvated one shift to high angles (\n). Interestingly, after immersing in DMF or MeOH again, it will restore to its original look. We deduce that the guest DMF in 1 is irregular, and has higher boiling point and bigger spatial volume than that of 1,4-dioxane, so the framework of 1 shows a little expansion to encapsule big guest molecule and less thermal stability after releasing the guest.

The permanent microporosity of 1 degassed under a dynamic vacuum at 160°C for 5h, was established by reversible gas sorption experiments using N2 at 77K. Gas adsorption measurements (N2, H2, and CO2) were performed on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 surface area and pore size analyzer. The experiments shows typical type I behavior (
), which is characteristic of microporous materials. The maximum N2 uptake at 1bar for 1 is 28.36cm3
g−1 (STP). The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) and Langmuir surface areas for 1 are estimated to be 78.1 and 113.9m2

g−1) at 273K, and 1.92mmolg−1 (43cm3
g−1) at 298K, respectively. Virial analysis of the CO2 adsorption isotherms revealed that the isosteric heat of adsorption of 1 at zero surface coverage is 24.5kJ/mol (Fig. S5). g−1) and 298K (3.73cm3
g−1). We employed the Henry’s constants to estimate the adsorption selectivity of 1 for CO2/N2
, which has been shown to be valid for calculating the gas selectivity of MOFs, 1 is calculated to exhibit an adsorption selectivity of 36.6 for CO2 over N2 at 273K and 25.3 at 298K respectively, which indicated that 1 has excellent CO2/N2 adsorption selectivity. Catalytic epoxidation of olefins and allylic alcohols in the presence of [CuMoO4(N2C12H8)]·H2O (1) and ([Cu3
ICl(4,4′-bipy)4][CuII(1,10-phen)2Mo8O26]) (2)

The prepared crystals were tested as catalyst in the liquid-phase epoxidation of some olefins and allylic alcohols using TBHP as oxidant. As seen in 
, the prepared catalyst can act as active and selective catalyst in the epoxidation of the selected olefins and allylic alcohols. 3-methyl-2-butene-1-ol as a representative substrate was chosen for the early exploration of the reaction conditions. The obtained results for the catalytic epoxidation of 3-methyl-2-butene-1-ol with TBHP within various reaction times are presented in 
. It is evident that the epoxidation of 3-methyl-2-butene-1-ol proceeds rapidly in the first 30min with the conversion of 85%, but then it continues more slowly until it is mostly oxidized within 4h beyond which no considerable oxidation occurs. Blank experiment performed in the absence of the catalyst gave low conversion (28%) after 2h under the same conditions. In order to provide a better insight into the catalytic activity of compound 1, the crystals of compound 2 were prepared according to the procedure described in the literature  and utilized as heterogeneous catalyst for the epoxidation of 3-methyl-2-butene-1-ol. The results (shown in ) revealed that the epoxidation of 3-methyl-2-butene-1-ol in the presence of compound 2 proceeds slowly within 3h.

Water, methanol, and benzene sorption isotherms were also measured at room temperature. Virtually no water adsorption can be observed for the MAF-4 and MAF-5, demonstrating they are very rare hydrophobic adsorbents with high porosity. In contrast, MAF-7 have been shown moderate hydrophilicity and interesting water sorption behavior () . The MeOH sorption behaviors of these porous MAFs are very different from those for H2O. As illustrated in 
, all the three materials can adsorb large amounts of MeOH corresponding to their pore volumes. All the sorption isotherms can be described as being type-IV, with abrupt increases of uptakes started at P/P
0
=0.13, 0.12, and 0.015 for MAF-4, MAF-5, and MAF-7, respectively. The type-IV isotherms indicate that the host–guest interactions are weaker than the guest–guest ones. In other words, at low relative pressures, the adsorbents form weak interactions with the hydroxyl group and methyl groups of MeOH. Capillary condensation above the onset pressures are ascribed to hydrogen-bonding interactions among the adsorbed MeOH molecules. The lowest onset pressure of MAF-7 should be ascribed to the presence of uncoordinated nitrogen donors on its pore surface.

Results and discussion

Syntheses and characterizations

Compounds 1\u20133 were synthesized through the hydrothermal reactions of bpp, OH-H2BDC with CoII, NiII and CdII salts, respectively. Similar to the previous reports by us and some other groups, the \u2013OH group of HO-H2BDC is not involved in coordination to the transition metal ions and only serves as a donor for hydrogen bonds to stabilize the structures of 1\u20133 (see below), however, the \u2013OH group as an electron-donating group may influence the self-assembly process although the reaction mechanism still remains unclear, because the expected results were not obtained when using m-isophthalic acid (H2BDC) instead of HO-H2BDC under the same hydrothermal condition. The IR spectra of the three compounds exhibit strong characteristic vibrational bands of the carboxylate groups. For 1, the characteristic bands of the carboxylate groups are shown at 1575cm\u22121 for the antisymmetric stretching band and 1401cm\u22121 for the symmetric stretching band. The separation (\u0394) between \u03bd\nasym(CO2) and \u03bd\nsym(CO2) is 174cm\u22121. For 2, one antisymmetric stretching band (1562cm\u22121) and two symmetric stretching bands (1412 and 1357cm\u22121) are exhibited, the \u0394 values are 150 and 205cm\u22121, respectively. For 3, the typical antisymmetric and symmetric stretching bands of carboxylate groups are at 1564 and 1387cm\u22121, with a \u0394 value ca. 177cm\u22121. The results are consistent with the different coordination modes of the carboxylate groups in the three compounds, one coordination mode in 1 and 3, two coordination modes in 2 () .

Crystal structure of compound 3


Compound 3 is a twofold interpenetrated three-dimensional framework with free water molecules as space fillers. As shown in 
, each CdII center is in a distorted pentagonal bipyramidal geometry. Two chelating carboxylate groups from different OH-BDC ligands and one pyridyl nitrogen atom from a bpp ligand comprise the equatorial basal plane, one water molecule and one pyridyl nitrogen atom from the other bpp ligand occupy the apical sites [OW1–Cd–N1 168.5(2)°]. The CdII center is displaced about 0.221Å from the equatorial plane towards the axial donor atom. The Cd–O and Cd–N bond distances are in the range 2.284(5)–2.614(5)Å and 2.324(6)–2.341(5)Å, respectively. Different from 1 and 2, OH-BDC acts as a chelating bis-bidentate ligand ((c)) and bridges different CdII centers to give rise to a one-dimensional metal-carboxylate chain (
). Exo-bidentate bpp adopts a TG conformation with the dihedral angle between two pyridyl rings being 79.4°, which is similar to that in 1. Thus bpp links the adjacent one-dimensional chain into a three-dimensional framework with large channels (
). The Cd⋯Cd distances bridged by bpp and OH-BDC are 11.967 and 10.117 Å, respectively. In order to shrink the void space and stabilize the final product, the three-dimensional network is interpenetrated into itself to generate an interwining network (
). Free water molecules are accommodated in the residual empties and further stabilize the structural framework through extensive hydrogen bonding interactions between coordinated water molecules and carboxylate oxygen atoms of OH-BDC [OW1–H⋯O1i 2.679Å, (i) −x
+1, −y
+1, −z
+1], between coordinated water molecules and free water molecules [OW1–H⋯OW3ii 2.856Å, (ii) −x
+1, y, −z
+3/2], between free water molecules and carboxylate oxygen atoms of OH-BDC [OW2–H⋯O2ii 2.900Å], between free water molecules and free water molecules [OW4–H⋯OW5 2.116Å], as well as between hydroxyl groups of OH-BDC and free water molecules [O5–H⋯OW5 2.700Å].

The charge-transfer property of the compounds can be further illustrated by cyclic voltammetric study ((c)). The oxidation peak of the [Ru(Bpy)3]2+ cation is 1.29\u00a0V in acetonitrile (E\n1/2, vs. SCE, oxidation onset potential 1.15\u00a0V), while that of compound 4 is observed at about 1.25\u00a0V (E\n1/2) (\u0394E\u00a0=\u00a040\u00a0mV, oxidation onset potential 1.10\u00a0V) under the same experimental conditions. The negative shift of the Ru(III)/Ru(II) redox potential is due to the charge transfer from the cadmium chalcogenido cluster anion to the [Ru(Bpy)3]2+ cation, considering also the charge-transfer band appeared in spectra. The negative scan of compound 4 under Ar atmosphere shows a reduction peak of the cluster at about\u00a0\u22121.0\u00a0V with the onset potential\u00a0\u22120.8\u00a0V ().

Photocurrent responses

The CdQ materials are usually photoelectric active and have been interesting until now for their application in photoelectronic materials, but such property has been seldom studied for the cadmium chalcogenido clusters with charge transfer property based on our knowledge. To reveal the photoelectric activity of the charge transfer compounds, a three electrodes photoelectrochemical cell was constructed (a more detailed description is given in the experimental section). Linear sweep voltammograms were recorded both in the dark and light irradiation to profile the I\u2212V relationship (\n). The current intensity is related to the applied potential and the wavelength of the light. The electrochemical system displays a zero current platform at about\u00a0\u22120.66\u00a0V vs. SCE (open circuit potential). The onset potentials of the dark current are at\u00a0\u22120.10\u00a0V and\u00a0\u22121.24\u00a0V for anodic and cathodic currents, respectively. Photoinduced anodic current enhancement is clearly observed for the electrochemical system. Photo-enhanced current at applied potential 0.0\u00a0V vs. SCE is found about 19.5\u00a0\u03bcA (no filter applied and the datum deducted from the line in dark). The observable photocurrent responses extend to visible range (>420\u00a0nm), while the current intensity (absolute value) decreases quickly when the cut wavelength increases.

\n\n shows the photocurrent responses as the excitation light was turned on and off. A sharp photocurrent was generated when the cluster/ITO electrode was subjected to excitation with UV and visible light. The irradiation process was repeated 20 times over 400\u00a0s, and the UV light was cut at 380\u00a0nm or 400\u00a0nm. The reproducible photocurrent responses without noticeable decrease in their relative intensities, despite of the dissimilar base curves, demonstrate the repeatabilities of the photoelectrode responses and hence the mechanical and photophysical stabilities of the electrodes. It should be noted that the current intensity is related to the wavelength of the light and the type of the clusters. The results are summarized as following. (1) The current intensity using a 380\u00a0nm UV filter (, the left) is larger than that using a 400\u00a0nm UV filter (, the right), about 1.7 times. (2) The current intensities of the 3-D C2 clusters are larger than those of the discrete C1 clusters, comparing (a) and (b) with (e) and (f), (c) and (d) with (g) and (h) in , about 2 times. (3) The current intensities of the selenide clusters are larger than those of the sulfide clusters, comparing (a) and (b) with (c) and (d), (e) and (f) with (g) and (h) in , about 8\u201310 times. (4) Dark current was clearly found for both the C1 and C2 selenide clusters ((a), (b), (e) and (f), shown in red lines), and for this reason the base lines of their photocurrent drop down in whole or in first part of the experiment range. The different intensities of sulfide clusters and selenide clusters clearly indicate the important roles of the elements in CdQ clusters.

When comparing the crystal structure of lanthanide maleates  to the crystal structure of rare earth fumarates, one can notice that two hydrogen maleate ions by one O atom form the coordination bond to the Ln3+ ion, while there are six O atoms from carboxyl groups in the present fumarate complexes that are attached to each rare earth ion (see  and \n). Also, the coordination modes of the carboxylate ions are different in both complexes. As is generally known, six coordinating fashions of the \u2013COO\u2212 ion may be described . In lanthanide fumarate crystals, three of them occur: chelating-type bidentate, bridging bidentate, and tridentate chelating-bridging. In the rare earth maleate crystal, there was only one coordination form of the carboxyl ions \u2013 the monodentate type  . The careful analysis of the presented X-ray data makes it possible to consider the differences of the polarizability values (\u03b1) of oxygen atoms as ligating atoms, especially considering the type of the coordinating carboxyl ion. These kinds of O atoms should probably be at different places on the ordinal scale of covalency, what should be reflected in the spectroscopic properties of the investigated crystals . A comparison of the average Sm\u2013O distance for both (maleate and fumarate) samarium compounds suggests that the character of the Ln\u2013O bond (2.503\u00c5) is more covalent for maleate than for fumarate (2.513\u00c5) (see ). Such a character of the Sm\u2013O bond should be reflected in the spectroscopic properties of investigated crystals.

The careful analysis of the low temperature emission spectra of the Sm2(C4H2O4)3·8H2O crystal makes it possible to notice that some electronic components of 4G5/2

The fumarate ligands in the present structure act as bridges between Ln3+ ions, thus giving rise to the chain structure. Such systems are very effective in ion-ion interactions and energy migration along the chain, which largely depends on the shortest intrachain Ln3+–Ln3+ distances. The average distance between neighboring rare earth ions in the fumarate chain (4.28Å) (see ) is smaller than 5Å. Thus, Sm3+ ions in these compounds can interact between each other through the “carboxylate bridges” of the fumarate anions, which is reflected in their spectra as the splitting of the crystal field components of f–f transitions. The determination of which components originate from ion–ion interactions needs additional investigations for fumarates concentrated and diluted by “innocent” ions (La3+, Ce3+, or Y3+).

Two interpenetrating coordination polymers are assembled from ZnII and 4-(2-ethyl-1H-imidazol-1-yl)benzate.

The synthetic methods include solvothermal condition and layer diffusion.

They display 3-fold pcu and 4-fold dia interpenetrating networks.

Interconvertible structural transformations between them are studied.

Two interpenetrating coordination polymers are assembled from ZnII and 4-(2-ethyl-1H-imidazol-1-yl)benzate.

The synthetic methods include solvothermal condition and layer diffusion.

They display 3-fold pcu and 4-fold dia interpenetrating networks.

Interconvertible structural transformations between them are studied.

Long-standing interest in the area of coordination polymers (CPs) or metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) stems from their tectonic aesthetics of crystalline architectures and potential functions in fields of optical, magnetic, electronic, catalysis, chiral, and microporous crystalline materials . At this stage, design of the target materials is based upon the sophisticated selection and utilization of specific organic and inorganic building tectons . Furthermore, some accessorial reaction parameters, such as pH , solvent , anion , and additive , are also critical for the fabrication of well-defined CPs. In comparison, studies on the regulation effect of CPs and their reversible structural transformations, via tuning distinct synthetic approaches, have been rarely reported . As a continuation of our research , we will present herein two distinct Zn(II) CPs of [Zn2(2-eiba)3(OH)]\nn\n (1) and {[Zn(2-eiba)2](H2O)3}\nn\n (2) via solvothermal synthesis and layer diffusion method, respectively.\n\n1\nSynthesis of [Zn2(2-eiba)3(OH)]\nn\n\n(1). Mixture of Zn(NO3)2\u00b76H2O (29.7mg, 0.1mmol) and 2-Heiba (21.6mg, 0.1mmol) in CH3OH (5mL) and H2O (5mL) was sealed in a Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 100\u00b0C for 3days. Colorless block single crystals of 1 were collected by cooling to room temperature at a rate of 15\u00b0C/h (yield: 15.6mg). Anal. Calcd for C36H34O7N6Zn2: C,54.49; H,4.32; N,10.59%. Found: C, 54.68; H, 4.29; N, 10.39%. IR (cm\u22121): 3401m, 3146m, 3058m, 1617vs, 1561m, 1513m, 1466m, 1379vs, 1307w, 1254w, 1176m, 1149w, 1107w, 1053s, 1009w, 960w, 879w, 849m, 788s, 743w, 722m, 644w, 617w, 584w, 547m, 524w, 504w, 458w, 411w. Synthesis of {[Zn(2-eiba)2](H2O)3}\nn\n\n(2). A methanol solution (3mL) of 2-Heiba (21.6mg, 0.1mmol) was carefully layered onto a water solution (3mL) of Zn(NO3)2\u00b76H2O (29.7mg, 0.1mmol) in a glass tube. Colorless block crystals of 2 were obtained by slow evaporation of the solvent at room temperature after three days (yield: 18.6mg). Anal. Calcd for C24H28N4O7Zn: C, 52.42; H, 5.13; N, 10.19%. Found: C, 52.46; H, 5.18; N, 10.11%. IR (cm\u22121): 3405b, 1632vs, 1575w, 1510m, 1462m, 1361vs, 1308m, 1251w, 1172m, 1147w, 1110w, 1053s, 1012m, 874w, 843m, 787m, 704m, 574m, 546m, 513m, 442w.\n Single-crystal X-ray structural analyses reveal that they display different entangled architectures, 3-fold and 2+2\u21924-fold types, respectively. More interestingly, interconvertible structrual transformations between 1 and 2 can be achieved with intensive rearrangement of the overall crystalline lattice. Thermal stability and fluorescence properties of these complexes have also been studied.

Characterization of Ni-HTP and NiRu-HTP

The well-aligned nanowire arrays of Ni-HTP were grown directly on carbon paper as electrodes through the coordination of Ni2+ with 2,3,6,7,10,11-hexaiminotriphenylene (HTP) in a hydrothermal reaction (Figure S1). NiRu-HTP was prepared by partially replacing Ni sites with Ru via an ion-exchange method. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images of NiRu-HTP and Ni-HTP electrodes are shown in a and S2, respectively. The directional nanoarrays densely surround the carbon fibers of about 30 nm in diameter and ~1 μm in length, which induce the hierarchical porous structure to benefit electron transfer, gas diffusion, and exposure of catalytic active sites. The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images of NiRu-HTP and Ni-HTP nanowires manifest high crystallinity and interplanar spacing of 1.8 nm, as displayed in b and S3. Inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) measurement of NiRu-HTP indicates that the contents of Ru and Ni are 37 and 63%, respectively.

X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of NiRu-HTP and Ni-HTP in c and S4a suggest their high crystalline features. Pawley refinements were conducted to simulate their crystal structures, which reveal that they can be assigned to the hexagonal structure. The prominent peaks at 4.7, 9.4, 12.4, and 16.5° are corresponding to the (001), (002), (210), and (004) facets, respectively, indicating the long-range order within the ab plane. Their comprehensive crystallographic information is depicted in Table S1, and their main structure variations are the lattice constants and unit cell volume. The Ni or Ru atoms are coordinated with the tritopic HTP linkers to form hexagonal units in Ni-HTP or NiRu-HTP with the layered graphene-like honeycomb structure, as depicted in d and S4b. The enlarged HRTEM image of NiRu-HTP perpendicular to the c-axis in e presents an ordered honeycomb arrangement of hexagonal pores of 2.0 nm along the [001] direction, which is consistent with the simulated structure of NiRu-HTP. The molecular structures of NiRu-HTP and Ni-HTP were disclosed in Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) of Figure S5. The three peaks at 1273, 1513, and 1619 cm-1 are ascribed to the stretching vibrations of C-C, C-N, and CN bonds in NiRu-HTP and Ni-HTP, respectively. The stretching vibration peak of C-N upshifts from 1502 cm-1 (H-N-C, HTP) to 1513 cm-1 (Ru/Ni-N-C) due to the formation of Ni-N or Ru-N bonds in NiRu-HTP and Ni-HTP, along with the peak disappearance of Ar-NH2 at 3275 cm-1.

X-ray absorption spectroscopy is employed to study the coordination of Ni and Ru in Ni-HTP and NiRu-HTP. g displays the X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) spectra of Ni K-edge in NiO, Ni-HTP, and NiRu-HTP. The edge positions of Ni-HTP and NiRu-HTP are approaching that of NiO, indicating that the Ni species are positively charged with the valence state of +2, in consistence with XPS (Figure S6b). The extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) spectrum of Ni-HTP displays its characteristic peak at 1.3 Å, and it is assigned to the Ni-N bond (h). The EXAFS fitting indicates the average coordination number of 4 on Ni within Ni-HTP (Figure S8), corresponding to the Ni-N4 units, in line with the resolved crystal structure in Figure S4. The XANES spectra of Ru K-edge in i suggest that the edge position of NiRu-HTP is located between Ru foil and RuO2, revealing that Ru exists with the valence state between 0 and +4. The Fourier-transformed EXAFS spectrum of NiRu-HTP in j exhibits a characteristic peak of 1.47 Å for the Ru-N bond, and its fitting indicates an average coordination number of 4 for Ru-N in Figure S8. In comparison with Ru foil and RuO2, no characteristic peaks of Ru-Ru bonds in NiRu-HTP can be observed and suggest the atomically dispersed Ru sites. The wavelet transform (WT) analyses are further performed for the Ru K-edge XANES spectra of NiRu-HTP (k). It displays a WT intensity maximum at ~5.0 Å-1 for the planar Ru-N coordination, which is obviously different from RuO2 and Ru-Ru bonds at 10.5 Å-1 in Ru foil. This verifies the atomic dispersion of Ru-N4 in NiRu-HTP.

Electronic Structure of NiRu-HTP and Ni-HTP

The electronic structures of NiRu-HTP and Ni-HTP are uncovered by the density functional theory (DFT) calculations. According to the total density of state (TDOS) analyses in a,b, the continuous electron occupation of Ni-HTP and NiRu-HTP near the Fermi level (E f) suggests that both possess a high electrical conductivity. The obviously larger electron density of NiRu-HTP near E f than that of Ni-HTP implies a higher electrical conductivity, which is confirmed by the conductivity measurements in Figure S9. In addition, the fully symmetric electron state densities of Ni-HTP indicate that the Ni atoms are of low spin with no single electron. In NiRu-HTP, the electron state densities near E f are asymmetric and spin-polarized, which is attributed to the plentiful single electrons on Ru atoms, contributing to the gas adsorption and activation. Generally, the d-orbital energy level center (E d) is considered as a good descriptor to evaluate the adsorbate-metal interaction and electrocatalytic activity. The integration of TDOS of Ni-HTP and NiRu-HTP yields the E d of -1.82 and -1.43 eV for Ni-HTP and NiRu-HTP, respectively. The higher E d of NiRu-HTP than that of Ni-HTP suggests the enhanced O2 adsorption and higher oxygen reduction activity. The valence band maxima (E VB) of Ni-HTP and NiRu-HTP are estimated to be ca. -0.32 and 0.07 eV, respectively (Figure S10). Since the valence electrons are approaching E f and mainly contribute to the d states, it allows the distinctly higher d-orbital energy level of NiRu-HTP than that of Ni-HTP, in accordance with the abovementioned TDOS analyses.

PDOS calculations are performed to investigate the interplay between Ni-HTP/NiRu-HTP and O2 molecules, as plotted in c,d. The electronic interaction is regarded as the coupling of molecular orbitals of O2 with d orbitals of metal nodes, giving rise to the orbital splitting to form the separated bonding and antibonding orbitals in Figure S11. The bonding states locate far below the E f and are generally fully filled, while the electron filling of antibonding states is decided by the position of d-orbitals relative to E f and contributes to the bonding strength. Obviously, NiRu-HTP manifests a significantly higher E d and larger hybridization degree with the 2p orbitals of O2 than Ni-HTP, which implies its higher bonding strength with O2. Specifically, at the Ni-N4 site, the d xz  and d yz  orbitals of Ni are overlapped with π orbitals of O2 to generate the (d xz /d yz -π)* orbitals, as shown in c. For the Ru-N4 site, the       d     z   2        and d xz  orbitals of the Ru site are coupled with the σ and π orbitals of O2 to constitute the respective (      d     z   2       -σ)* and (d xz -π)* orbitals, as plotted in d. As compared with the (d xz /d yz -π)* in Ni-HTP, the (      d     z   2       -σ)* and (d xz -π)* in NiRu-HTP displays a lower electron occupancy and higher energy level, which suggest the enhanced O2 adsorption and boosted Ru-O2 interaction. The O2-enrichment capabilities of NiRu-HTP and Ni-HTP are confirmed by low-pressure O2 adsorption at 298.25 K (Figure S12). Their O2 uptake linearly rises as a function of pressure, and NiRu-HTP exhibits an O2 adsorption of 7.02 cm-3 g-1 under an ambient atmosphere, obviously outperforming Ni-HTP (3.33 cm-3 g-1), suggesting the stronger O2 adsorption on NiRu-HTP.

Electrochemical Performance and Mechanistic Analyses

 a displays the cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves of NiRu-HTP and Ni-HTP with voltages ranging from 2.0 to 4.0 V. In the cathodic sweep, they present successive reduction peaks, indicating the continuous generation of LiO2 and Li2O2. During the reverse sweep, two distinct oxidation peaks are ascribed to the stepwise oxidation of Li2O2 with the LiO2 intermediate. Compared with Ni-HTP, NiRu-HTP shows the larger current density, as well as larger ORR onset potential (~2.76 V) and smaller OER onset potential (~2.98 V), suggesting its better electrocatalytic activity. The electrochemical performance of Ni-HTP and NiRu-HTP cathodes in b is examined at 500 mA g-1. The total polarizations during charge/discharge of Ni-HTP are 3.98/2.67 V with a low energy efficiency of 67.1%. In contrast, NiRu-HTP presents the discharge and charge voltages of 2.74 and 3.62 V, respectively, suggesting an overvoltage of 0.88 V and energy efficiency of 75.7%. c shows the charge/discharge curves of NiRu-HTP and Ni-HTP with a limited voltage of 2.20 V. NiRu-HTP and Ni-HTP cathodes show the respective ultrahigh capacities of 15,080 and 18,280 mA h g-1, which are attributed to their hierarchically porous structures and superior electrical conductivity. Meanwhile, NiRu-HTP displays a much smaller charge/discharge polarization (~1.20 V) than Ni-HTP, indicating the enhanced ORR and OER kinetics on NiRu-HTP for the Li2O2 formation and decomposition.

d,e depicts the rate capability of Ni-HTP and NiRu-HTP cathodes at the different current densities. The charge/discharge overvoltages are 0.76, 0.90, and 1.03 V for the NiRu-HTP cathode at 200, 500, and 1000 mA g-1, respectively. This is in contrast to the rapidly increased voltage hysterisis of Ni-HTP at the identical testing condition in e. f shows the plot of the overvoltages of NiRu-HTP and the other MOF-based cathodes at 200 mA g-1. Notably, NiRu-HTP presents the lowest overvoltage and is approaching the benchmarking RuO2. Their cycling performance is examined at 500 mA g-1 and presented in g. NiRu-HTP can sustain for 200 cycles with no obvious voltage drops, suggesting excellent cycling stability, while Ni-HTP operates for 150 cycles, followed by rapid voltage increase to 4.2 V. NiRu-HTP has no redox activity as indicated in Figure S13, and its superior electrochemical performance is favored by the superior catalytic activity for ORR and OER and high electrical conductivity.

The O2 consumption and generation during discharge and charge of NiRu-HTP are quantitatively analyzed with differential electrochemical mass spectrometry (DEMS). The charge-to-O2 ratios are 2.06 and 2.03 e-/O2 during discharge and charge in Figure S15, respectively, suggesting an approximate two-electron reaction for Li2O2 formation and decomposition without detectable CO2. The discharged and charged NiRu-HTP after 50 cycles were analyzed by XPS, as shown in Figure S16, revealing the main discharge product of Li2O2 with minor Li2CO3. Simultaneously, the cycled NiRu-HTP is confirmed to be highly stable with XPS and FTIR analyses in Figures S17 and S18, respectively, in agreement with no metal loss of Ni or Ru during cycles as revealed by ICP-MS of the separators extracted from Li-O2 batteries (Table S3).

The evolution of morphologies of the discharge products on Ni-HTP and NiRu-HTP is recorded with SEM at varied cutoff capacities in d,e and S19. At the capacity of 1 A h g-1, toroidal Li2O2 particulates of ca. 0.5 μm in size are grown in the interspace of Ni-HTP nanowire arrays. As the capacity changes to 2 and 5 A h g-1, more toroidal Li2O2 is accumulated to fully cover the electrode surface of Ni-HTP. However, on NiRu-HTP, Li2O2 presents a unique film-like morphology among the nanowires with a limited capacity of 1 A h g-1. When the capacity increases to 2 and 5 A h g-1, the film-like Li2O2 is gradually thickened to fill the void interspace of NiRu-HTP nanowire arrays. A similar morphology is well retained at the fully discharged NiRu-HTP in Figure S20. This contributes to the facile charge transfer and ion diffusion across the NiRu-HTP cathode/electrolyte interface, as verified by EIS in Figure S21 and Table S4, which favors the oxidative decomposition of Li2O2 in Figure S22 with reduced overvoltages. These suggest tunable kinetic behaviors of Li2O2 formation and oxidation, consistent with the battery performance in .

Luminescence Properties

It is well-known that MOFs comprising d10 metal ions and conjugated organic ligands are regarded as promising candidates in the fields of luminescence materials. The solid luminescence spectrum of H2FDA, 1, Cu  2+  @1, Co  2+  @1, and Ni  2+  @1 have been measured at room temperature (). Upon excitation at 260 nm, the emission spectrum of H2FDA exhibits a main emission with the maximum value of 465 nm, ascribed to π* → π and/or π* → n electronic transitions. Compared to the H2FDA ligand, a similar red shift of ca. 22 nm is observed for 1, Cu  2+  @1, Co  2+  @1, and Ni  2+  @1 upon excitation at 320 nm. Consequently, the emission peaks at 487 nm of 1, Cu  2+  @1, Co  2+  @1, and Ni  2+  @1 appear, assigned to the intraligand π* → π or π* → n transition of the ligand that was perturbed by metal ions.

Further explorations on the relationship between the changes of luminescence of 1 and the concentration of 2% acetylacetone were examined in detail as well. As shown in a, the curve showed the relevant changes of the luminescence intensity of 1 could be clearly observed and the quenching effects simultaneously became remarkable, showing an excellent sensitivity for sensing acetylacetone. Moreover, the luminescence intensity of 1 decreased sharply to 57.6% at the concentration of 3.88 μmol/L acetylacetone, and the intensity of 1 decreased to 79.2% when the concentration of acetylacetone reached 10.36 μmol/L. The decreased intensity of 1 with the increasing acetylacetone suggested the presence of the luminescence quenching effect of 1. The relationship between the quenching efficiency of 1 and the concentration of acetylacetone was illustrated in b. As a result, a best fit of I 0/I, and the concentration of acetylacetone was established with a equation of I 0/I = 1.0197 + K sv[acetylacetone] (inset of b), where K sv stands for the quenching constant (M-1), I 0 and I are the luminescence intensities before and after the addition of acetylacetone, and [acetylacetone] is the molar concentration of acetylacetone (mM), respectively. The result demonstrates a linear correlation of luminescence quenching and the concentration of acetylacetone and is in close proximity to the Stern-Volmer (SV) equation: I 0/I = 1 + K sv[acetylacetone]. The average K sv value was calculated to be 1.86 × 105 L mol-1 by the linear regression of the plot, indicating the significant quenching efficiency of 1 after the adding acetylacetone. The detection limits for acetylacetone can be calculated by using 3δ/k, in which δ is standard error and k is slope according to the Stern-Volmer equation with a value of 0.647 μmol L-1 for 1, further indicative of an excellent sensitivity for sensing acetylacetone.

The commercial application of lithium-oxygen (Li-O2) batteries has been seriously hindered by their large overpotential and inferior cycling performance caused by the insoluble and insulated traits of the discharge product, Li2O2. Herein, hierarchical hollow NiCo-LDH/MnO2 hybrid nanostructures derived from metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are successfully constructed as cathodes for Li-O2 batteries to fundamentally improve the decomposition kinetics of Li2O2. The hollow NiCo-LDH/MnO2 nanostructures assembled by hollow NiCo-LDH and MnO2 nanosheets possess a highly special surface area, abundant open active sites, and a fast diffusion path for Li+ and oxygen species. As expected, accelerated sluggish oxygen reduction reaction/oxygen evolution reaction kinetics and reduced charge/discharge overpotentials can be obtained. The toroidal Li2O2 assembled by nanoflakes formed on the surface of the cathode can be conducive to form a low-impedance Li2O2/cathode contact interface to achieve the reversible formation and decomposition of Li2O2. The Li-O2 battery based on the NiCo-LDH/MnO2 cathode shows a high charge/discharge specific capacity of 13,380 mA h g-1 at 100 mA g-1 and a continuous cycling stability for 162 cycles at a fixed capacity of 500 mAh g-1 as well as a low overpotential of 0.63 V. Moreover, the application of MOF-derived porous hierarchical nanostructures expands the selection range of electrocatalysts and offers a new idea of structure design for Li-O2 batteries.

Herein, an efficient strategy to construct novel hollow NiCo-LDH/MnO2 hierarchical nanostructures as cathodes for LOBs is developed. Specifically, the hollow NiCo-LDH nanocages are formed by ZIF-67 as the self-template, and then the ultrathin MnO2 nanosheets are grown on the NiCo-LDH nanocages. The LOBs based on NiCo-LDH/MnO2 nanostructures display a lower overpotential (0.63 V) and a higher capacity of 13380 mA h g -1 at a current density of 100mA g-1 as well as excellent cycling stability (163 cycles at 100 mA g -1) because of the synergistic effect of NiCo-LDH and MnO2. NiCo-LDH/MnO2 nanocages modulate the Li2O2 growth mechanisms of the surface-adsorption pathway and the solvation-mediated pathway to induce the formation of unique porous toroidal Li2O2 assembled by densified nanoflakes with poor crystallinity. This unique structure offers a large specific surface area and accelerates the complete decomposition of Li2O2 during the OER.

The crystal structures of the NiCo-LDH, MnO2, and NiCo-LDH/MnO2 samples are determined using the X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns. From a, the broad diffraction peaks at 11.7, 23.7, 34.2, and 60.1° can be assigned to the (003), (006), (012), and (110) planes indexed to the Ni(OH)2 phase (JCPDS no. 38-0715). In addition, the diffraction peaks located at 12.5, 25.0, 36.8, and 65.5° are attributed to the (003), (006), (101), and (110) planes of δ-MnO2 (JCPDS no. 86-0666), respectively. The composition and chemical bonding states of the hollow NiCo-LDH/MnO2 nanocages are further confirmed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The survey scan of the XPS spectrum (Figure S3) shows the presence of the peaks of Co 2p, Ni 2p, Mn 2p, Mn 3s, Mn 3p, and O1s. For the Co 2p spectrum, the peaks at 795.9 and 780.7 eV correspond to 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 of Co2+, and the peaks at 790.4 and 774.5 eV are correspond to Co3+. The high-resolution XPS Ni 2p spectrum (c) also can be fitted into four peaks, which correspond to the Ni 2p3/2 and Ni 2p1/2 of Ni2+ (855.5 and 873.1 eV) as well as the satellite feature (874.3 and 856.6 eV). In the Mn 2p spectrum, the Mn 2p3/2 (642.1 eV) and Mn 2p1/2 (653.8 eV) peaks can be accounted for Mn4+. Additionally, the O 1s peak in e can be deconvoluted into two peaks. The peak at 529.8 eV is assigned to the Mn-O functional group and the distinct peak at 531.1 eV is associated with the hydroxide groups, suggesting the formation of NiCo-LDH. According to the elemental contents measured by XPS (Table S2), the weight ratio of MnO2 is about 36% in the NiCo-LDH/MnO2 composite.

Electrochemical Performance of Electrocatalysts in LOBs

The electrochemical performances of NiCo-LDH, MnO2, and NiCo-LDH/MnO2 electrodes are comparatively investigated. The electrochemical measurement results are calculated on the basis of the total weight of cathode catalysts (NiCo-LDH or MnO2 or NiCo-LDH/MnO2) and Super P. a displays the cyclic voltammogram (CV) plots of the three electrodes at a scan rate of 0.1 mV s-1 within the voltage range of 2.0-4.5 V. The CV plot of the NiCo-LDH/MnO2 hybrid catalyst electrode exhibits a single cathodic peak at around 2.44 V, which is ascribed to the oxygen reduction (O2 + 2Li+ + 2e- → Li2O2), while the two oxidation peaks located at 3.41 and 4.36 V are ascribed to the stepwise delithiation and the bulk oxidation process of Li2O2 (Li2O2 → O2 + 2Li+ + 2e-), which are higher than those of NiCo-LDH and MnO2 monophase catalyst electrodes. Compared with two monophase catalysts, the hybrid catalyst delivers a higher ORR onset potential and a lower OER onset potential, revealing the higher ORR and OER catalytic activity. In addition, the higher ORR and OER peak current and integrated area indicate that there are more Li2O2 generation/decomposition.

b depicts three galvanostatic discharge/charge profiles in the voltage window of 2.0-4.5 V versus Li+/Li with NiCo-LDH, MnO2, and NiCo-LDH/MnO2 cathodes at a current density of 100 mA g-1. By comparison, the NiCo-LDH/MnO2 cathode exhibits a high discharge capacity (13380 mA h g-1) with the reversible ORR/OER process, while the NiCo-LDH and MnO2 electrodes can only exhibit capacities of 5380 and 9360 mA h g-1. It should be noted that the discharge capacities are mainly contributed by ORR (Figure S6). In addition, the NiCo-LDH/MnO2 catalyst also plays a significant role in reducing the polarization of LOBs. The NiCo-LDH/MnO2 cathode exhibits a flat discharge plateau of 2.66 V and a charge midcapacity potential (defined as the voltage at half capacity) of 4.0 V with the lower polarization (approximately 0.30 and 1.04 V during discharge and charge). However, the overpotential of NiCo-LDH and MnO2 is 1.47 and 1.59 V, respectively, marking the generation and decomposition of Li2O2 more difficult, and the side reactions are exacerbated during the discharge/charge process for monophase catalyst cathodes. Therefore, NiCo-LDH/MnO2 with enhanced OER and ORR catalytic activity can effectively improve the electrochemical performance of LOBs.

Light and Dark Cytotoxicity

Before investigating the PDT therapeutic agents, the dark and light cytotoxicity of the MOF-NH2, Ce6@MOF, and CPC@MOF to cancer cells was investigated by a standard 3-(4,5-dimethylthiazol-2-yl)-2,5-diphenyltetrazolium bromide (MTT) system ( and S8). More than 90% viability of MOF-NH2-incubated HeLa cells treated with/without 660 nm laser irradiation indicated the low cytotoxicity for both MOF skeleton and laser irradiation. After HeLa cells were treated with Ce6@MOF for 7.5 h, the cells could maintain a high viability of 91.1%, suggesting the tolerance of its low dark cytotoxicity. However, the enhanced apoptosis percentage of Cam@MOF or CPC@MOF-treated HeLa cells with the increasing amount of Cam encapsuled in the MOF demonstrated the pharmacological effect of Cam due to the efficient loading/release of Cam (Figure S8). Meanwhile, the viability of the cells treated with Ce6@MOF or CPC@MOF greatly decreased with increasing laser irradiation time due to the recovered photosensitivity of Ce6 cleaved by intracellular CaB (). These results demonstrated the low dark cytotoxicity, high light cytotoxicity, and enhanced therapy efficiency of CPC@MOF.
