Fluorescence Imaging and Chemo-Photodynamic Therapy of CPC@MOF

The confocal imaging of HeLa cells was performed to evaluate the therapeutic effectiveness of Ce6@MOF and CPC@MOF (). After a 5 min laser post-irradiation of Ce6@MOF-incubated cells for 7.5 h, a few bubbles appeared on the surface of HeLa cells, and the fluorescence spot of Ce6 gradually diffused from lysosomes to cytoplasm resulting from the destruction of lysosome. Meanwhile, the apoptotic apperance of HeLa cells was observed after incubation with Cam@MOF for 7.5 h, at which time Cam showed a considerable release efficiency from the MOF skeleton as a result of the diffusion from the pores and/or drug-matrix interaction (Figure S9). However, no obvious morphological change of Cam@MOF-treated cells occurred under laser irradiation after 7.5 h of incubation, which was caused by the absence of CaB-activated Ce6. To access the collaborative treatment of chemotherapy and PDT, the HeLa cells were incubated with CPC@MOF for 7.5 h and then treated with the laser irradiation for 5 min. On the one hand, lots of bubbles appeared on the cell surface, and the cells exhibited significant morphological change. On the other hand, flow cytometry analysis, which was conducted by Annexin V-FITC together with PI apoptotic kit, was used as dual-fluorescence probe to distinguish viable cells from dead cells after treatment with CPC@MOF (B). Combining both chemotherapy and PDT effect of CPC@MOF, a total of 99.27% HeLa cells showed apoptosis under laser irradiation with the power of 200 mW cm-2 for 5 min. However, only 35.17% apoptotic percentage of CPC@MOF-treated HeLa cells without laser irradiation could be achieved by the effect of Cam in MOF. These results indicated that chemo-photodynamic therapy of CPC@MOF could achieve a desirable therapeutic efficacy.

Next, a series of flow cytometric apoptosis assay was performed to test the synergistic therapy efficiency of the CPC@MOF (). The laser dose including irradiation time and laser power used in the PDT process should be taken into consideration. As shown in A, the total apoptosis ratio of the Ce6@MOF-treated Hela cells increased with the exposure time and reached nearly 99.26% until 30 min, which was much longer than the time for CPC@MOF-treated cells (5 min). The assay of the HeLa cells treated with Ce6@MOF displayed growing apoptosis degree under increasing laser power (Figure S10) and gained the satisfactory apoptosis degree at 500 mW cm-2, which was comparable to the effect of CPC@MOF with the power of 200 mW cm-2, demonstrating the good therapy performance of multifunctional CPC@MOF probe. Besides, the treatment time was also an important factor in the therapy process. As shown in B for Cam@MOF, 53% apotosis ratio of pure drug-treated HeLa cells needed the long treatment time of 30 h. In comparison, above 99% apotosis ratio of CPC@MOF-treated cells was achieved after 7.5 h of incubation and 5 min of laser irradiation at 200 mW cm-2. These results manifested that a better therapy efficiency could be achieved by the synergistic antitumor effect both the chemotherapy and CaB-depended PDT of CPC@MOF.

Effects of Reaction Temperature

Comparing with the above-mentioned influences, another the key parameter is the reaction temperature for the formation of ZIF-8 based on the following reasons: First, the reaction temperature affects the solubility of Hmim. Second, it may play a crucial role in coordination mode of Hmim. Finally, it directly affects the reaction energy in reaction thermodynamics and kinetics. Consequently, the reaction temperature can be used as a structure direct factor in the synthesis of ZIF-8. Specifically, Tsai and co-workers have systematically studied the effect of temperature on the particle size distribution of nano-ZIF-8. In their experiment, the average ZIF-8 nanoparticle size decreased to 26 from 78 nm with increasing the reaction temperature from -15 to 60 °C. At the same time, the external surface area increased from 220 to 336 m2⋅g-1. As a result, an improved catalytic activity could be achieved in comparison with ZIF-8 microparticles. The reason why the size decreased as the temperature increased is the relationship between nucleation and temperature. At higher temperatures, faster nucleation happens which results in a high concentration of nanoparticles, whereas the nucleation rate slows at lower temperature and leads to fewer nucleating particles, which would grow to form larger particles in the presence of a lot of starting materials.

Decomposition of DMF to Formic Acid

This band increases shortly after formation of the MOF nuclei in solution, rising sharply between 3 and 4 h before leveling off at around 4.2 h to reach a final area corresponding to a formic acid concentration of 0.44 mol L-1.

The X-ray diffraction pattern (b) indicates a rise in crystallinity of MIL-53(DMF) particles isolated between 3.6 and 3.9 h. Although the sample taken at 3.6 h consists of small nanoparticles, the sorption isotherm at 77 K (after calcination) shows a high nitrogen uptake at low relative pressures corresponding to the presence of micropores (d). The calculated BET area of 897 m2 g-1 for the sample taken at 3.6 h accounts for approximately two-thirds of the accessible surface area reported for hydrothermally synthesized MIL-53. All nitrogen isotherms (d) show an additional uptake above p/p 0 > 0.9 and a more or less pronounced hysteresis loop, which is caused most likely by nitrogen condensation in the interstitial voids between the nanoparticles. The isotherm of the sample taken at 3.6 h, however, displays a type H4 loop with a forced hysteresis loop closure around p/p 0 ~ 0.45. This phenomenonreferred to in the literature as the tensile strength effectis often observed when microporous crystals such as zeolites form disordered aggregates. We conclude that at the onset of precipitation MIL-53 platelet nanocrystals aggregate in a disordered way, creating interparticulate pores in the nanometer range. We suppose that the cavities are connected to the outer surface of the aggregates by the MOF micropores, thus forming an ink-bottle pore network. Consequently, the MOF pores (bottle necks) prevent the depletion of the inner voids, until the desorption branch reaches a critical p/p 0 value (p/p 0 ~ 0.4 to 0.5 for N2 at 77 K) and the cavities are instantly emptied by cavitation-induced effects.

In this study, we demonstrate the functioning of a heavy-metal ion trap formed by grafting l-cysteine (l-cys) onto Zr4+-based MOF-808 [Zr6O5(OH)3(BTC)2(HCOO)5(H2O)2] via postsynthetic ligand exchange (PSLE) to form MOF-808-cys. l-Cys is well-known as a source of S2- for the synthesis of a variety of metal-sulfide NPs, many of which are prominent photo- and electrocatalyst systems. The tolerance of MOFs linked by Zr4+-based clusters towards harsh chemical and mechanical conditions makes them ideal platforms for introducing functionalities employing PSLE, and MOF-808 is itself a robust system with a wide pore arrangement. The resulting functionalized MOF showed structural retention and affinity towards heavy-metal ions such as Cd2+ in aqueous media. In situ growth of CdS NPs inside the MOF pores was realized at elevated temperatures under mild reaction conditions. Moreover, it is well established that the Zr4+ cluster is capable of acting as a cocatalyst for photocatalytic water splitting or CO2 reduction. Therefore, the confinement of CdS NPs in the MOF nanopores in close proximity to the Zr4+ cluster not only opens up a facile and shorter electron transfer channel that suppresses electron-hole recombination but also stabilizes the catalytic system by preventing self-agglomeration and photobleaching (). The observed rate of H2 evolution from water for CdS4@MOF-808 (composite with 3.56 wt % of CdS) is 10.41 mmol h-1 g-1. The pore confinement effect of CdS was realized by comparing the catalytic activity with that of the CdS/MOF-808-cys (catalyst with similar CdS loading but on the exterior MOF surface) nanocomposite, which showed 60 times lesser activity with much slower and inefficient electron transfer kinetics compared to CdS4@MOF-808, as realized by the transient absorption (TA) measurements.

Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Structural Characterization

Zr4+-based MOF-808 formulated as Zr6O5(OH)3(BTC)2(HCOO)5(H2O)2 has a 6,3 connected 3D framework with spn topology and possesses two types of cages: tetrahedral and adamantane. The adamantane cage, having an internal pore diameter of 16.1 Å, is formed by the tetrahedral cages acting as the vertices. To balance the charge, the coordination of the SBU is completed with five exchangeable formate ligands that are well-directed toward the spacious adamantane cage. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern of the as-synthesized MOF-808 (a) exhibited two peaks at 8.6 and 9.9°, typical of MOF-808. Importantly, the observed pattern demonstrated unshifted peaks when compared with the simulated pattern obtained from its single-crystal structure analysis. The as-synthesized MOF-808 was also characterized employing FT-IR spectroscopy (Figure S1) and 1H NMR spectroscopy (Figure S2). The morphology of MOF-808 was studied by transmission electron microscopy (TEM), wherein octahedral particles of size around 200-250 nm were observed (d). The lattice fringe spacing calculated was 1.64 nm, which is typical for MOF-808, and the result is consistent with the pore size obtained from the non-local density functional theory (NLDFT) methods based on N2 adsorption data at 77 K (d inset). N2 adsorption study (at 77 K) was performed to validate the permanent porosity of MOF-808 (b). The BET surface area was 2418 m2 g-1, which is in good agreement with the previous reports of Zr4+-based MOF-808. The high internal surface area, large cavity size, excellent stability in aqueous solutions, and, most importantly, the presence of appropriately oriented and exchangeable formate ions on the Zr6 cluster makes Zr4+-based MOF-808 an ideal platform for postsynthetic modification with l-cys. The robustness of the structure of MOF-808 after functionalizing with l-cys was confirmed by PXRD studies (a), where similar peak positions were observed when compared with the pristine MOF-808. 1H NMR studies of alkaline digested MOF-808 exhibited two characteristic peaks at chemical shift values of 8.28 and 8.20 ppm corresponding to the protons of benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylate (BTC) and formate ligands. The peak integration ratio of these two peaks confirmed the presence of six BTC and five formate units in the framework. However, for MOF-808-cys, this resulting ratio indicated the presence of six BTC units and one formate unit, thereby confirming the successful exchange of four formate ligands by l-cys (Figure S4). The FT-IR spectra for MOF-808-cys showed two new peaks at 2310 and 1190 cm-1 corresponding to the S-H and C-N symmetric stretching, respectively, further confirming the presence of the l-cys molecule in the MOF-808 framework (Figure S3). TEM images of MOF-808-cys (e,f) reveal an octahedral morphology, thereby confirming no significant change in morphology upon covalent grafting of l-cys. The presence of S and N in the elemental mapping of MOF-808-cys (g and S5) also illustrates the incorporation of l-cys into the framework.

Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) measurements (Figure S6) demonstrated weight loss in two steps and a total of 40 and 56% weight loss up to 800 °C for MOF-808 and MOF-808-cys, respectively. It was also observed that MOF-808-cys could maintain good thermal stability up to 250 °C, which is in good consistency with that of pristine MOF-808. A significant decrease in the N2 uptake (b) and the corresponding BET surface area from 2418 to 562 m2 g-1 further validates the incorporation of l-cys in the framework. The pore size distribution (c) showed a reduction of pore size from 1.60 to 0.86 nm after postsynthetic modification with l-cys. However, the cavity size for MOF-808-cys is still spacious enough for efficient mass transfer to take place.

CdS1@MOF-808 exhibited considerable absorption of visible light, as evident from a significant peak at 410 nm in its absorption spectrum (a). This peak at 410 nm was attributed to the charge transfer from the valence band (VB) primarily having the 3p character of the S atom to the empty CB, which majorly has the 5s character of the Cd2+ center. Interestingly, CdS is one of the most prominent visible-light-responsive semiconductor photocatalysts for solar-fuel generation due to its efficient visible-light absorption and excellent carrier transport capacity. Herein, the band gap of CdS1@MOF-808 was calculated to be 2.60 eV from the Tauc plot (Figure S19), thereby suggesting a narrow band gap that is suitable for visible-light-driven photocatalysis as opposed to the wide band gap of around 4.02 eV observed for MOF-808-cys (Figure S18). The flat band potential and, consequently, the relative alignment of the VB and CB were evaluated from the Mott-Schottky plots (b,c). The observed flat band potential of the sample is -0.51 V. The suitable band alignment and narrow band gap of CdS1@MOF-808 enthused us to study its photocatalytic activity for the visible-light-driven hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) by water reduction. Herein, the photocatalytic activity of an aqueous dispersion of CdS1@MOF-808 was evaluated under visible-light (λ > 400 nm) irradiation by employing triethylamine (TEA) as the sacrificial agent, and the time course for H2 evolution was monitored by gas chromatography (d). After a period of 12 h, 1.01 mmol g-1 H2 evolved. To enhance the photocatalytic activity of the nanocomposites even further, the wt % of CdS formed was enhanced to 1.84 and 3.56% by increasing the concentration of the Cd2+ aqueous solution to 50 and 150 ppm, and the samples were named CdS2@MOF-808 and CdS4@MOF-808, respectively. The robustness of the structure of these two samples was verified by PXRD analysis (Figure S16). In line with the morphological analysis of CdS1@MOF-808, CdS NPs of 1-2 nm diameter were found confined inside the MOF pores and not on the exterior surface of the MOF for both CdS2@MOF-808 and CdS4@MOF-808 (d, S20, and S21). However, further drastically increasing the concentration of the aqueous solution of Cd2+ to 0.1 M led to the formation of larger CdS NPs (size ~ 20 nm) on the MOF surface (Figure S22), and therefore, the CdS loading inside the pore was not amplified beyond what was obtained for CdS4@MOF-808. Both CdS2@MOF-808 and CdS4@MOF-808 showed similar absorption spectra and flat band potential (Figures S23 and S24) as that observed for CdS1@MOF-808, and hence, the photocatalytic activities of these two samples were tested subsequently. The amount of H2 evolved after 12 h of reaction shot up from 2.42 to 125.79 mmol g-1 for CdS2@MOF-808 and CdS4@MOF-808, respectively (d,f). Recyclability of CdS1@MOF-808, CdS2@MOF-808, and CdS4@MOF-808 as photocatalysts was tested under similar reaction conditions by degassing the samples after every 4 h cycle. The photocatalytic performances of all samples were consistent even after 4 cycles (e and S25) and hence were rendered extremely stable. Notably, CdS4@MOF-808 demonstrated an extremely high photocatalytic activity with a rate of 10.41 mmol g-1 h-1. Raman spectroscopy is an extremely effective tool to study small changes corresponding to the local environment of the molecule, chemical bond, and so forth. The Raman peak observed at 303 cm-1 for the pristine CdS NPs corresponds to the first-order longitudinal optical phonon (A1-LO) scattering from the CdS NPs (Figure S26). Interestingly, in case of CdS4@MOF-808, this peak shifted to a higher energy value at 401 cm-1. This could possibly be attributed to the freezing of several degrees of rotational and vibrational freedom owing to the confinement inside the MOF nanopores. After 12 h of photocatalytic reaction, the Raman spectrum of CdS4@MOF-808 showed no changes for the peak corresponding to CdS and for the MOF peaks, thereby suggesting no change in its chemical composition and interaction of the elements. The surface charge of CdS4@MOF-808 was analyzed by ζ-potential measurements before and after photocatalysis (Figure S27). CdS4@MOF-808 shows an intense peak at a ζ-potential value 0 mV, indicating the fact that the net surface charge on the MOF is neutral. A similar phenomenon is observed for the sample after 12 h of photocatalytic reaction, thereby signifying no change in the surface charge of the MOF. The photocatalytic activity of CdS4@MOF-808 was analyzed in basic (TEA), acidic (l-ascorbic acid), and neutral (methanol) media (Figure S28). Since the H2 evolution activity observed in basic media was the highest, further HER studies were carried out in basic media using TEA as the sacrificial agent. In order to confirm the photocatalytic HER by CdS4@MOF-808, several control studies were carried out under varying reaction conditions (Figure S29). No H2 evolution was observed from a visible-light irradiated mixture of H2O and TEA, thereby ruling out the possibility of any H2 generation from the solvent or sacrificial agent. Negligible H2 was evolved using bare MOF-808-cys or even MOF-808-cys-Cd, where Cd2+ ions are simply coordinated to the l-cys moiety under visible-light irradiation using TEA as the sacrificial agent. This, in turn, highlights the importance of formation of CdS NPs inside the MOF for efficient photosensitizing, which is crucial for photocatalysts. Finally, the lack of H2 generation by CdS4@MOF-808 in the dark with otherwise similar reaction conditions confirms the photocatalytic nature of the HER. The apparent quantum efficiency after irradiation at 400 nm was calculated to be 3.28% for CdS4@MOF-808 (see Supporting Information for detailed calculation). HER tests using CdS4@MOF-808 were also performed for a time course of 36 h to demonstrate consistent performance and long-term stability of the photocatalyst (Figure S30). Intactness of the pristine MOF structure was confirmed by PXRD analysis, and the morphological stability of CdS4@MOF-808 was confirmed by TEM analysis, wherein no agglomeration or leaching of CdS NPs were observed (Figures S31 and S32). The H2 evolution activity of CdS4@MOF-808 without an external photosensitizer or cocatalyst was more or less equal to or greater than several recently reported NP-MOF composite photocatalysts (Table S2).

Effect of Pore Confinement on Catalytic Activity

The development of new and innovative routes for stabilization of the charge-separated states by suppressing charge recombination in photocatalysts has been a topic of immense interest for years. In this context, it was observed that photoinduced electron transfer (PET) from the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) of the CdS moiety to the empty LUMO of the Zr4+ cluster of MOF-808-cys could open up a catalytic path for manifesting in excellent photocatalytic activity of the system. Confinement of CdS NPs in close proximity to the catalytic center, that is, the Zr4+ cluster, helps dock and separate electron-hole pairs by opening up a shorter electron transfer route, resulting in stabilization of the excited-state electron and rendering it more available for catalytic reactions. To study this phenomenon in detail, a comparative study was carried out between two photocatalytic systems, CdS4@MOF-808 and CdS/MOF-808-cys, having different locations of CdS NPs in the MOF-808 (Figure S33). Unlike CdS4@MOF-808, in case of CdS/MOF-808-cys, the presynthesized CdS NPs of 1-2 nm were stabilized on the surface of MOF-808-cys. From ICP-OES analysis, the amount of CdS present in CdS/MOF-808-cys was found to be 3.82 wt %, which is almost equal to that observed for CdS4@MOF-808. TEM images of CdS/MOF-808-cys showed the presence of CdS NPs on the external surface of the MOF (e). The photocatalytic activity observed for CdS/MOF-808-cys (0.15 mmol g-1 h-1) (f) was almost 60 times lower compared to that observed for CdS4@MOF-808. Recyclability tests demonstrated that the photocatalytic activity of CdS/MOF-808-cys gradually decreases with each cycle (Figure S25). Although the crystalline MOF structure remains intact post-photocatalytic reaction (Figure S34), considerably large agglomerations of CdS NPs on the MOF surface were observed for CdS/MOF-808-cys (Figures S38-S40). However, CdS NPs in CdS4@MOF-808 continued to maintain a uniform dispersion inside the MOF pores, as validated from TEM and FESEM images (Figures S35-S37). This further accentuates the fact that in an unconfined state, CdS NPs tend to agglomerate and undergo photobleaching, thereby reducing the overall photocatalytic activity of the system. To gain an insight into the factors responsible for such differential activity of the two samples, photocurrent response and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) studies were carried out. The photocurrent response (a) of the as-prepared samples was examined in a three-electrode photoelectrochemical cell with multiple 30 s on-off cycles under visible-light irradiation. CdS4@MOF-808 exhibited a much higher current density as compared to CdS/MOF-808-cys, suggesting a large separation rate of the photoinduced electron-hole pairs, and consequentially, higher efficiency of charge transfer from CdS to the MOF in the former was conjectured. The EIS-Nyquist plot of CdS4@MOF-808 (b) demonstrated a smaller circular radius than that of CdS/MOF-808-cys, therefore indicating a lower charge-transfer resistance of the former sample. Moreover, the photocurrent response and EIS analysis of MOF-808-cys individually revealed negligible charge transfer, thereby emphasizing the importance of CdS in this system for any PET process to occur, and most importantly, the enhanced charge-transfer efficiency of CdS4@MOF-808 compared to CdS/MOF-808-cys solely arises from the confinement of the CdS NPs inside the MOF pores. Furthermore, photophysical studies were employed to investigate the efficiency of charge carrier trapping and transfer in the photocatalysts. The photoluminescence (PL) emission spectra of both CdS4@MOF-808 and CdS/MOF-808-cys (c) showed a peak at 504 nm corresponding to the radiative recombination of the photogenerated electrons and holes. However, significant quenching of PL intensity was observed for CdS4@MOF-808 as compared to that of CdS/MOF-808-cys, indicating that the former showed enhanced separation efficiency of the photogenerated electron-hole pairs. The lifetime of the charge carriers was studied via luminescence decay measurements (d and Table S3), wherein CdS4@MOF-808 demonstrated a shortened lifetime value of 2.02 ns as compared to CdS/MOF-808-cys, which has a lifetime of 4.03 ns. To further understand the charge-transfer kinetics of the photogenerated electrons and origin of higher current density in CdS4@MOF-808 than CdS/MOF-808-cys observed in EIS studies, femtosecond TA experiments were performed. The TA spectra of CdS/MOF-808-cys in the visible region for different times are shown in Figure S41a. At initial time, the spectra of the sample showed a negative TA band (B1) with a peak ~480 nm and a broad negative band (B2) spanning over 520-700 nm. The TA spectra of the sample also revealed a positive absorption band (A1) below 440 nm. Following the literature report, B1, B2, and A1 bands are assigned to the exciton bleach due to the state filling of the 1S(e) level at the CB of CdS, stimulated emission, and the excitonic absorption due to the presence of multiple excitons, respectively. Significant quenching of all three bands in the presence of methyl viologen clearly indicates that an electron rather than a hole mainly contributes to these spectral bands (Figure S41b). Since the excitonic bleach band B1 represents the population of the electron in the 1S(e) state, its dynamics corresponds to the depopulation of the electron at the CB. Hence, to understand the fate of electrons, the dynamics of the B1 band has been analyzed. The fitting of B1 band decay kinetics results in the decay time constants of 0.83 ps (33%), 21 ps (53%), and 3.12 ns (14%) for CdS/MOF-808-cys. The two fast decay time constants are due to the trapping of the electron in the shallow and deep trap state, respectively. The longest lifetime (3.12 ns) is due to the recombination of the CB edge electron with the trapped hole. A similar TA spectral feature has been observed for CdS4@MOF-808 (e) except that the B1 band is centered at ~460 nm than 480 nm in CdS/MOF-808-cys. Such difference in the spectral position is due to the agglomeration of CdS NPs in CdS/MOF-808-cys. The kinetics of the B1 band for CdS4@MOF-808 has been compared with CdS/MOF-808-cys, and the result is shown in f. Similar analysis of the B1 band for CdS4@MOF-808 results in the decay time constants of 0.22 ps (44%), 13.2 ps (31%), and 384 ps (25%). Hence, the lifetime of excitonic electrons in the CB of CdS NPs reduces significantly due to its incorporation inside the MOF cavity as compared to the CdS NPs residing on the external surface of the MOF. This result is also in accordance with the significant quenching of PL and shorter PL lifetime in CdS4@MOF-808 than CdS/MOF-808-cys.

The exploring of oxygen electrocatalysts with outstanding durability and efficiency toward the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) is greatly desired for zinc-air flow batteries (ZAFBs). Herein, NiCo alloy-based nanoparticles anchored on carbon nanotube-decorated carbon nanorods (CNRs) used as a durable and efficient oxygen electrocatalyst for ZAFBs were obtained from the pyrolysis of NiCo metal-organic frameworks synthesized by a facile oil bath method. By tailoring the ratio of Ni2+ and Co2+, the prepared sample, Ni2Co2-CNR, exhibits excellent ORR (E 1/2 = 0.80 V) and OER catalytic performances (a low overpotential of 310 mV at 10 mA cm-2). Impressively, the ZAFB assembled with a Ni2Co2-CNR catalyst shows a narrow voltage gap and remarkable operation durability with 1200 cycles at 5 mA cm-2 with every cycle of 20 min.

Inspired by the above, in this article, a highly efficient, low-cost, and stable bifunctional electrocatalyst containing NiCo alloy nanoparticles and a small fraction of CNTs, which are tightly anchored and decorated on carbon nanorods, respectively, (Ni x Co y -CNR), is presented. Also, the whole synthetic process is overwhelmingly simple and facile, which only involves an oil bath method and subsequent calcination. The hybrid catalyst with a suitable ratio of Ni2+and Co2+ (Ni2Co2-CNR) shows positive electrocatalytic activities and stability toward ORR (E 1/2 = 0.80 V) and OER (a low overpotential of 310 mV to reach 10 mA cm-2) compared to the 20 wt % Pt/C and IrO2 catalysts, respectively. What is most impressive is that when Ni2Co2-CNR is integrated into the ZAFB, a high peak power density (122.1 mW cm-2) and energy density (784.5 mA h gZn -1) can be achieved. In addition, ZAFBs fabricated with Ni2Co2-CNR also exhibit an anticipated long-time cycling performance without obvious decay (1200 cycles at 5 mA cm-2 with every cycle of 20 mins). The synergetic effects that stem from the carbon framework (carbon nanorods and CNTs) and NiCo alloy nanoparticles are considered as the major contributions for the enhanced electrocatalytic activity.

The XRD patterns obtained from five different samples are presented in l. Ni4Co0-CNR without the addition of Co2+ displays a pure Ni phase and its three distinctive peaks located at 44.5, 51.8, and 76.3° are assigned to the (111), (200), and (220) planes of Ni (PDF#04-0850), indicating that Ni2+ from the precursor of Ni4Coy-MOF is successfully reduced to Ni nanoparticles during the process of calcination. Subsequently, after the introduction of Co2+ in the synthetic steps, the diffraction peaks of the obtained three samples (Ni3Co1-CNR, Ni2Co2-CNR, and Ni1Co3-CNR) shift to lower angles and are located between those of Co (PDF#15-0806) and Ni (PDF#04-0850), demonstrating the formation of single-phase alloyed NiCo nanoparticles. Although the information concerning carbon peaks is not discovered from the XRD results, this phenomenon does not manifest the inexistence of carbon components. Obviously, the Raman spectrum of the five samples is diagnostic of the presence of carbon species. As shown in m, all samples display two peaks centered at about 1335 cm-1 (D-band) and 1585 cm-1 (G-band), respectively. The D-band and G-band derive from the defective carbon (sp3) and graphite carbon (sp2) atoms, respectively. The ratio of I D/I G of Ni2Co2-CNR is 1.01, smaller than those of Ni4Co0-CNR (1.04), Ni3Co1-CNR (1.21), Ni1Co3-CNR (1.06), and Ni0Co4-CNR (1.04), indicative of the improved degree of graphitization of Ni2Co2-CNR. The boosted degree of graphitization is expected to trigger an enhanced electrical conductivity, which favors acceleration of the charge transfer rate during the electrolysis.

The high-resolution of the Co 2p spectrum of Ni0Co4-CNR (b) can be fitted into four components, which are Co0 (779.42 eV and 794.44 eV), Co3+ (795.37 and 780.66 eV), Co2+ (782.48 and 797.54 eV), and satellite structure (786.56 and 803.08 eV). Meanwhile, the peaks of Co0 from Ni1Co3-CNR, Ni2Co2-CNR, and Ni3Co1-CNR were shifted to lower binding energies of about 1.09, 0.75, and 0.71 eV, respectively, with respect to the monometallic Ni0Co4-CNR. Such an observed shift reflects a modification of the electronic structure between the near-surface Co and Ni atoms. It also demonstrates the formation of the NiCo alloy and the existence of bimetallic synergic effects. Such a phenomenon can also be verified from the high-resolution Ni 2p spectra of all samples. As shown in c, the high-resolution Ni 2p spectrum of Ni4Co0-CNR can also be deconvoluted into eight peaks, displaying four Ni species. The peaks at 852.61 and 870.98 eV are attributed to Ni0 in the NiCo alloy. The peaks located at 853.77 and 873.47 eV correspond to Ni3+ the peaks at 855.74 and 877.97 eV are consistent with those of Ni2+, and the other peaks located at 860.70 and 880.81 eV are assigned to the satellite structure. Similarly, the peaks of Ni0 from Ni3Co1-CNR, Ni2Co2-CNR, and Ni1Co3-CNR were also shifted to lower binding energies of about 0.01, 0.39, and 0.03 eV, respectively, confirming the presence of NiCo alloy. Ascribed to the formation of the NiCo alloy, the Co atoms can obtain d electrons from the nearby Ni atoms, increasing the electron-donating feature of the hybrids, which may improve the electrochemical activity. d shows the high-resolution O 1s spectrum, and the peaks at 529.88 and 531.58 eV are attributed to oxygen species.

e,f displays the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm and the corresponding pore diameter distribution curves of Ni x Co y -CNR. Obviously, they all exhibit a typical type IV hysteresis loop, confirming the existence of micro/mesoporosity in the as-synthesized catalysts. In addition, the specific surface area (SSA) and the maximum pore width of Ni2Co2-CNR are measured to be 154.93 m2 g-1 and 23.1 nm, respectively. Also, the sample of Ni0Co4-CNR has no pores according to the pore diameter distribution curve. The mesoporous structure has a positive impact on the mass transfer and rapid diffusion of O2, thus providing a highly accessible surface area and more active sites for the electrolysis.

Electrocatalytic Properties

To assess catalytic performance toward ORR, the five samples' powder as well as 20% Pt/C were tested for linear sweeping voltammograms (LSV) in O2-bubbled 0.1 M KOH solution with a rotation speed of 1600 rpm at a scan rate of 5 mV s-1. As displayed in a and Table S3, without the addition Co2+ in the precursor, even the diffusion limiting current density of Ni4Co0-CNR does not achieve -4 mA cm-2, whereas after the introduction of Co2+ in the precursor, Ni3Co1-CNR, Ni2Co2-CNR, and Ni1Co3-CNR can reach higher values above -4 mA cm-2, indicating that the synergetic effects between NiCo alloy nanoparticles and carbon nanorods can enhance ORR performance. More remarkably, Ni2Co2-CNR shows pleasurable ORR catalytic activity confirmed by the limiting current density (-5.15 mA cm-2) and half-wave potential (E 1/2 = 0.80 V) being more positive than those of Ni4Co0-CNR, Ni3Co1-CNR, and Ni1Co3-CNR, although they are slightly lower than those of 20% Pt/C. However, with the continuous increase of Co2+ until Ni2+ is totally replaced by Co2+, the limiting current density of Ni0Co4-CNR is still unsatisfactory. All the above discussions demonstrate that Ni2Co2-CNR possesses the best ORR electrocatalytic performances. The excellent ORR activity of Ni2Co2-CNR can further be verified by the Tafel slope displayed in b. It can be seen that the Tafel slope of Ni2Co2-CNR is 83 mV/dec, much lower than that of Ni4Co0-CNR (150 mV/dec), Ni3Co1-CNR (138 mV/dec), Ni1Co3-CNR (123 mV/dec), and Ni0Co4-CNR (127 mV/dec) and even comparable to that of Pt/C (70 mV/dec), which validates the preferable kinetic process of Ni2Co2-CNR toward ORR. The prominent ORR performance of Ni2Co2-CNR may be attributed to the synergetic effects between NiCo alloy nanoparticles and carbon nanorods and high surface area and 3D interconnected network architecture stemming from carbon nanorods and CNTs.

LSV curves of Ni2Co2-CNR at different rotating speeds were also recorded to further gain insight into the ORR kinetics shown in c and Figure S1. Obviously, as the rotation rates increase, so does the limiting current density. The inset of c presents the corresponding Koutecky-Levich (K-L) plots of Ni2Co2-CNR and the lines are linear and parallel, indicating that O2 kinetics on the Ni2Co2-CNR catalyst follows first-order reaction kinetics. Also, the calculated electron transfer number (n) is determined in the range of 3.85-3.94, indicating that a typical four-electron reaction pathway is dominat during the ORR process for Ni2Co2-CNR. The n values for other samples are displayed in Figure S2. In addition, the n and peroxide yield (HO2 - %) are obtained according to the rotating ring disk electrode (RRDE) curves. As shown in Figure S3, Ni2Co2-CNR possesses comparable values of n (3.85) at 0.7 V, which matches well with the above result (the inset of c). Furthermore, the HO2 - % for Ni2Co2-CNR is 7.48% at 0.7 V, disclosing excellent selectivity for the ORR process.

Furthermore, the stability and durability of Ni2Co2-CNR were also tested because of their importance for the ORR reaction. Ni2Co2-CNR displays no obvious recession after adding methanol (3 M) into electrolyte, suggesting the excellent abovementioned property (d). In addition, when Ni2Co2-CNR is subjected to cyclic voltammetry (CV) tests for 4000 cycles, as presented in e, a negligible performance reduction (5 mV) negative shift toward E 1/2 is observed after tests. Figures S4 and S5 display the SEM, TEM, and corresponding mapping images after CV measurements. Clearly, many carbon rods are captured after tests, disclosing no obvious changes about its morphology. Furthermore, it is also interesting to notice that many CNTs marked in Figure S5b,c still can be observed. Figure S5d shows the homogeneous distribution of Ni and Co elements. Further, f displays the i-t curve of Ni2Co2-CNR and 20% Pt/C at a potential of 0.65 V. After about 43,000 s, the prepared catalyst can retain 84.1% of the initial current. On the other hand, its counterpart has only a relative current retention rate of 50.2%, which is ascribed to the corrosion of the amorphous carbon support and the possible Pt detachment and aggregation. In general, the above results reveal the outstanding durability and stability of Ni2Co2-CNR as an ORR electrocatalyst.

Under the same measurement conditions, the OER performances of the NiCo alloy series and the commercial IrO2 catalyst were also investigated and are exhibited in a. It is found that Ni2Co2-CNR not only shows favorable ORR performance but also outstanding OER activity. Apparently, a 310 mV overpotential to achieve 10 mA cm-2 is afforded by the Ni2Co2-CNR, lower than that of other ratios of NiCo alloy catalysts (Table S3) and IrO2. The better performance toward OER of Ni2Co2-CNR can be also validated from the Tafel slope value of all samples shown in b. One can see that Ni2Co2-CNR possesses a Tafel slope value of 135 mV/dec, lower than those of Ni4Co0-CNR (163 mV/dec), Ni3Co1-CNR (163 mV/dec), Ni1Co3-CNR (136 mV/dec), Ni0Co4-CNR (248 mV/dec), and IrO2 (232 mV/dec). This is perhaps attributed to the higher graphitization degree of Ni2Co2-CNR (m) and optimized electronic structure between NiCo alloy nanoparticles (b,c).

Additionally, because of the proportion between electrochemical active surface area (ECSA) and electrochemical double-layer capacitance (Cdl), CV measurements at different scan rates were conducted to calculate the value of C dl so as to further estimate ECSA. As shown in d and Figure S6, Ni2Co2-CNR displays the largest C dl determined to be 44.9 mF cm-2, higher than those of other as-synthesized samples, demonstrating that Ni2Co2-CNR can supply more active sites for redox reactions. The so many active sites of Ni2Co2-CNR is believed to be governed by its unique and abundant carbon structure including carbon rods and CNTs, which can expose more NiCo alloy sites, further resulting in remarkable OER performance.

Likewise, the durability is also a crucial indicator to assess the performance of a catalyst toward OER. Therefore, CV cycling and i-t techniques are carried out to verify the stability of Ni2Co2-CNR. First, as displayed in e, after 4000 cycles of CV cycling, the slight change of overpotential (10 mV) is afforded by Ni2Co2-CNR. Figure S7a shows the SEM image after OER tests of Ni2Co2-CNR. It can be observed that Ni2Co2-CNR keeps its original structure with obvious carbon rods. In addition, the high-resolution Co 2p and Ni 2p spectra after OER tests of Ni2Co2-CNR were also detected and are showcased in Figure S7b,c. However, the potential to achieve 10 mA cm-2 is positively shifted by 140 mV for IrO2. Then, an i-t chronoamperometric response test is conducted and the result is presented in f. After 12 h of continuous operation, the residual current percentage of Ni2Co2-CNR is 90.4%. Consequently, Ni2Co2-CNR also possesses promising durability toward OER processes.

Figure S8 displays a ZAFB with Ni2Co2-CNR displays an open circuit potential of 1.61 V after 600 s. b exhibits discharge polarization and corresponding power density curves for ZAFBs assembled with Ni2Co2-CNR and Pt/C + IrO2, respectively. It can be seen that the maximum power density of ZAFBs using Ni2Co2-CNR as the air electrode is 122.1 mW cm-2, higher than that of the Pt/C + IrO2-based ZAFB (93.6 mW cm-2). Galvanostatic discharge curves reveal that Pt/C-based ZAFBs can only maintain about 124.2 h under a current density of 10 mA cm-2. However, the ZAFB using Ni2Co2-CNR as the air cathode can work for more than 200 h although the discharge voltage of Ni2Co2-CNR is lower than that of Pt/C at the initial 100 h. With the continuous consumption of the zinc plate, the electrolyte of the ZAFB began to leak, resulting in the fluctuation of the curve shown in c. The inset of c shows the photograph of the zinc plate after the battery stopped working. The discharge potential plains of the ZAFB at different current densities were also tested and are showcased in d. At 10 mA cm-2, the voltage of the ZAFB equipped with Ni2Co2-CNR is lower than that of the ZAFB fabricated with Pt/C + IrO2. However, at higher current density, the voltage of Ni2Co2-CNR is apparently higher than its counterpart. Even though the current density was returned to 10 mA cm-2, the voltage rebounded to 1.17 V, disclosing a remarkable rate performance for Ni2Co2-CNR. Also, at 5 mA cm-2, the specific capacity of the ZAFB with Ni2Co2-CNR is 784.5 mA h gZn -1 by normalizing to the consumed zinc (e). f presents a ZAFB assembled with the Ni2Co2-CNR catalyst, which lightened a light-emitting diode (LED) board showing "DHU". In addition, two ZAFB in series can light a LED bulb, demonstrating its potential application.

Last but not least, to verify the excellent stability and durability of Ni2Co2-CNR, the galvanostatic cycling test of ZAFBs is further investigated with every cycle of 20 min. As shown in g, at 5 mA cm-2, the battery assembled by Pt/C + IrO2 fails quickly with a limited cyclability of 237 cycles (79 h). However, the battery fabricated by Ni2Co2-CNR displays an outstanding durability for 1200 cycles (400 h). Although, at the first cycle, the VG of Pt/C + IrO2 is 0.83 V (Figure S9), a little lower than that of the Ni2Co2-CNR-based battery (0.85 V) showcased in the inset of g. This may be attributed to the better ORR and OER catalytic activity from Pt/C and IrO2, respectively. Nevertheless, with the increment of cycles, the VG of Pt/C + IrO2 grows to 0.98 V after 200 cycles due to the poor stability of Pt/C or IrO2 while the VG of the battery assembled by Ni2Co2-CNR only reaches to 0.93 V at 500 cycles (the inset of g). This may be ascribed to the compatibility adjusted by the original charging and discharging operation, enhancing the sufficient electrochemical reaction, which is in favor of cycling performance. Consequently, even at 1200 cycles, the VG is merely 1.04 V (the inset of g). Figure S10 displays the SEM images of Ni2Co2-CNR after cycling tests. It can be clearly observed that Ni2Co2-CNR still retains the original rod-like shape, which is in accordance with the initial SEM images (h), demonstrating the prominent stability and durability of Ni2Co2-CNR.

The capture of water vapor at low relative humidity is desirable for producing potable water in desert regions and for heat transfer and storage. Here, we report a mesoporous metal-organic framework that captures 82% water by weight below 30% relative humidity. Under simulated desert conditions, the sorbent would deliver 0.82 gH2O gMOF -1, nearly double the quantity of fresh water compared to the previous best material. The material further demonstrates a cooling capacity of 400 kWh m-3 per cycle, also a record value for a sorbent capable of creating a 20 °C difference between ambient and output temperature. The water uptake in this sorbent is optimized: the pore diameter of our material is above the critical diameter for water capillary action, enabling water uptake at the limit of reversibility.

The pores are defined by one-dimensional chains of five-coordinate metal atoms with hydrophilic open coordination sites supported by strong metal-azolate linkages. Because of all these attributes, the materials exhibit exceptional stability toward polar analytes such as ammonia, and we anticipated that they would also have optimal water sorption properties. Water vapor adsorption isotherms were measured at 298 K for 1, 2, and 3 (A). All materials show type IV isotherms featuring a step in the uptake at approximately 0.28 P/P o (equivalent to RH = 28%), which is attributed to the onset of pore filling. Before this step, the water adsorbed is likely due to cluster adsorption around the open metal sites. For 1, the onset of pore filling is concurrent with pore collapse and structural rearrangement, as evidenced by the much lower total uptake of 0.389 gH2O gMOF -1, a powder X-ray diffraction pattern consistent with largely amorphous material (Figure S1), and a greatly reduced apparent surface area (Figure S2). In contrast, 2 and 3 exhibit large and steep uptake steps as their pores are filled with water. These materials remain crystalline after water sorption and retain their high BET surface areas of 1912 m2 g-1 and 1762 m2 g-1, respectively (Figures S3-S6). At 94% RH, the total water uptakes for 2 and 3 are 0.968 g g-1 and 0.766 g g-1, respectively (A). The lack of hysteresis between adsorption and desorption indicates continuous reversible pore filling rather than irreversible capillary condensation. The uptake of water between 10% and 30% RH is referred to as the deliverable capacity because uptake in this region is due to a process with a high enough driving force to be useful in AWG and AHP applications, while allowing low-temperature regeneration. B illustrates the superiority of 2, on a material basis in this humidity range, as compared to other MOFs and zeolites that have been investigated for their water uptake properties.

Owing to its superior water adsorption behavior, Co2Cl2BTDD (2) was investigated in greater detail with respect to its potential utility in AWGs and AHPs. The heat of adsorption for water in 2, determined by variable temperature water sorption isotherms fitted to the Clausius-Clapeyron equation, is approximately 55 kJ mol-1 at zero coverage and falls to 45.8 kJ mol-1 during pore filling (Figure S7). The latter is closer to the heat of vaporization for water, 40.7 kJ mol-1, and indicates that water-water interactions are dominant during pore filling. The variable temperature water sorption isotherms also allow the calculation of a characteristic curve, which converts the independent pressure and temperature variables governing uptake into a single parameter related to the Gibbs free energy of adsorption (see the Supporting Information). In turn, the characteristic curve allows for the extrapolation of an isotherm at a given temperature to temperature and pressure values relevant for various devices. The characteristic curve for 2 (Figure S8) was validated by measuring water vapor isotherms at 283, 293, and 298 K (Figure S9). We then used this characteristic curve to generate adsorption and desorption isotherms at temperatures relevant for AHP and AWG applications (Figures S10 and S11).

The potential of 2 to generate potable water in desert regions was evaluated by simulating realistic day/night temperature and RH conditions applicable in the Atacama, the Sonoran, and the Arabian deserts, among others: daytime values of 45 °C and 5% RH changing to nighttime values of 25 °C and 35% RH. Based on characteristic curve-derived isotherms under these conditions, 2 is predicted to capture 82% water by weight (wt %) at night and release it during the day (A). This is nearly double the previous best material reported for this application, MOF-841, which captures and releases only 42 wt % water. Cycling 2 under simulated desert daytime and nighttime conditions revealed an initial deliverable capacity of 84.7 wt %, in remarkable agreement with the characteristic curve predictions, a value that declined by only 5.1 wt % over 6 cycles (B). Highlighting the exciting prospects of 2 for water capture is an elegant recent proof of principle study showing a device that delivers 0.30 LH2O kg-1 MOF per cycle using MOF-801 as the active adsorbent. In a similar device, 2 is projected to capture and release 0.87 LH2O kg-1 MOF per cycle.

The thermodynamic parameters of water sorption in 2 highlight its exceptional performance at transferring heat. The water-2 fluid-adsorbent working pair achieves a 20 °C temperature lift, the range required for an air conditioner, for instance. This temperature difference can be achieved with a cooling capacity per cycle of ~400 kWh m-3 (A), at least 50 kWh m-3 higher than that of any known adsorbent, regardless of regeneration temperature. In a hypothetical AHP using low-grade heat sources, compound 2 can be regenerated using waste heat of only 55 °C (Figure S12). Such a device would have a material-based coefficient of performance (COP), defined as the ratio of useful cold energy output divided by input heat energy, of 0.885 (B). A measure of efficiency, COPs for AHP cooling applications vary from 0 to 1. Notably, the water-2 working pair has the highest COP for any fluid-adsorbent combination across a wide range of desorption temperatures. The high COP for this material is a direct result of its unusually high gravimetric water capacity: very little energy is expended on heating the adsorbent because less solid is required for a given water capacity relative to other adsorbents. Compound 2 is stable to cycling under AHP conditions as well (C). Cycling 2 between 25 and 120 °C at constant water vapor pressure of 13 mmHg revealed an initial gravimetric capacity greater than 1 g g-1, with a decline of only 6.3 wt % and no loss in crystallinity after 30 cycles (Figure S5).

Figure  shows the atomic structures of four MOFs (IRMOF-14, IRMOF-13, PCN-6', and PCN-6) examined under this study. IRMOF-14 has a cubic structure with a lattice constant of 34.38 Å. It is formed by substituting 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (BDC) in the prototype IRMOF-1 with pyrene-dicarboxylate (PDC), which is longer in length and leads to larger pores. The pore diameters in IRMOF-14 are approximately 20.1 and 14.7 Å. IRMOF-13 has a trigonal space group with unit cell lengths of a = b = 24.82 Å and c = 56.73 Å. Despite the identical metal oxide and organic linker in IRMOF-13 and IRMOF-14, IRMOF-13 has a catenated framework and differs in the topology from IRMOF-14. The pore diameters in IRMOF-13 are 12.4 and 8.7 Å, smaller than those in IRMOF-14 due to catenation. PCN-6' is a noncatenated structure with boracite net topology similar to that of Cu-BTC. The primary building block is 4,4',4''-s-triazine-2,4,6-triyltribenzoate (TATB) instead of benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylate (BTC) in Cu-BTC. It has a cubic structure with unit cell length of 46.64 Å and a void cuboctahedron with diameter 30.32 Å. The open square pores in PCN-6' are 15.16 × 15.16 Å2 or 21.44 × 21.44 Å2 along the edges or diagonals. PCN-6 is a catenated counterpart of PCN-6' and can be reproduced by two identical catenated nets of PCN-6'. It exists in the R-3m space group with cell dimensions of a = b = 32.97 Å and c = 80.78 Å. PCN-6 contains octahedral cages with edge length of 16 Å and triangular channels of 9.2 Å along the edge. The experimentally determined Langmuir surface area and pore volume are 2700 m2/g and 1.045 mL/g in PCN-6', which rise to 3800 m2/g and 1.453 mL/g in PCN-6. Apparently, catenation leads to an increase of 41% in surface area and of 39% in pore volume.

Figure a reports the evolution of both orientational and translational order parameters calculated for CO2 as function of the MD time. At the LP → NP transition boundary (t ~ 0.8 ns), where the unit cell volume drops suddenly from 1420 to 1050 Å3/u.c., one clearly observes a disorder → order orientational transition. The so-obtained drastic increase of S from 0.2 (LP) to 0.9 (NP) can be attributed to the high degree of confinement in the NP structure compared to that in the LP form, which tends to force the CO2 molecules to be strictly aligned along the z axis, as previously shown. An illustration of this highly ordered arrangement of CO2 in the NP form is provided in Figure b, where one might assume a smectic-like order with an interlayer distance of about 8.6 Å corresponding to the interpore length along the y axis. Further, the so-involved large loss of degree of freedom results in a quenched dynamics of CO2, implying an entropy decrease that is compensated by the strong host/guest interactions present in the NP form. It thus leads to a favorable free enthalpy (ΔG = ΔH - TΔS), which suggests that the structural transition is governed by an enthalpic driving force.

When changing H2O-C2H5OH solvent to H2O in the reaction system, 2 is obtained. Compound 2 also crystallizes in the monoclinic P2(1)/c space group and has a unique 3D→3D two-fold interpenetrating motif. There are two Cd(II) ions, two bimm ligands, two tdc ligands together with four lattice water molecules in the asymmetric unit ( a). The two crystallographically independent centers, Cd1 and Cd2, reside in similar coordination environments and are coordinated with four carboxylate oxygen atoms from three tdc ligands, and two nitrogen atoms from two bimm ligands, showing the distorted octahedral coordination geometry. As shown in (b), each deprotonated tdc ligand exhibits the (κ 1-κ 1-μ 2)-(κ 2)-μ 3 binding fashion to connect three Cd(II) ions to generate a 2D layer structure containing a similar [Cd2(CO2)2] subunit. The Cd⋯Cd distance and O-Cd-O angle within the [Cd2(CO2)2] core are 3.7794 (3)Å and 76.253(78)°, respectively. These dinuclear units are further connected to their subsequent neighbors through bimm ligands and generate a 3D framework (c). From the topological point of view, the structure of complex 2 can be represented as a uninodal 6-connected pcu network with a Schläfli symbol of 4120.63 (d) . The 3D pcu framework possesses large channels which allow further nucleation in the void space to generate a 2-fold interpenetrated structure, and thus reducing the void volume completely. PLATON calculations indicate that the effective volume is 515.7Å3 per unit cell, which is 15.8% of the crystal volume.

When replacing H2O with DMF solven, we obtained 3 as 8-connected 3D network with 1D open channels. Single-crystal X-ray analysis reveals that 3 crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group Pbca. The asymmetric unit consists of one Cd(II) ion, one bimm ligand, one tdc ligand together with one uncoordinated DMF molecule. As shown in  a, the coordination environment around 6-coordinated Cd(II) ion can be described as a distorted octahedral geometry, being coordinated by four carboxylate oxygen atoms of tdc ligands and two nitrogen atoms from two bimm ligands. The bond lengths of Cd-N are 2.309(3) (Cd-N2) and 2.278(3) Å (Cd-N5), while the Cd-O bond lengths vary from 2.225(2) to 2.609(3) Å, which are in the normal range. In 3, each tdc ligand adopts a (κ 1-κ 1-μ 2)-(κ 2)-μ 3 bridging fashion and connects three Cd(II) ions to produce a 2D layer structure with a [Cd2(CO2)2] subunit with an edge-sharing polyhedron along the ab plane (b). The Cd⋯Cd distance and O-Cd-O angle within the [Cd2(CO2)2] subunits are 3.7652 (5)Å and 76.457(82)°, respectively. The subunits are further connected to their subsequent neighbors through bimm ligands infinitely creating a 3D framework having small continuous 8.31×8.22Å channels along the a direction to which DMF guest molecules point (taking into account the van der Waals radii of the atoms) (c). The total potential solvent-accessible volumes of 3 are calculated to be 29.6% (1174.8Å3 out of 3968.7Å3 per unit cell volume) after squeezing DMF molecules by PLATON program. From a topological viewpoint, each [Cd2(CO2)2] core can be considered as a 8- connected node which links with eight neighboring [Cd2(CO2)2] subunits. Based on this simplication, the overall 3D network of 1 can be rationalized as a 8-connected body-centered cubic (bcu) topology with a Schläfli symbol of (4240.64) (d) .

Thermogravimetric analyses

Thermal behaviors of 1-3 have been characterized by thermogravimetric analysis ( ). No obvious weight loss was found for 1 before the decomposition occurred at about 230°C, which is in good agreement with the results of the crystal structure. For 2, a weight loss of 7.82% before 102°C indicates the exclusion of four water molecules (calc. 7.71%), and the host framework can be stable up to 269°C. For 3, there is no significant weight loss before 120°C, and then the gradual weight loss of 14.51% that takes place between 120 and 272°C corresponds to the removal of uncoordinated DMF molecules (calcd: 14.49%). Above 272°C, 3 begins to collapse of the framework, accompanied by the release of tdc and bimm ligands.

Luminescent properties

The luminescent properties of 1-3 together with free organic ligands were studied in the solid state at room temperature. As shown in  , the emission spectra for 1-3 exhibit main emission peaks in the range of 350-600nm at 412nm, 407nm, and 416nm upon excitation at 300nm, respectively. The free ligands display luminescence with emission at 354nm (λex=280nm) for bimm and 380nm (λex=300nm) for H2tdc, which may be ascribed to the π*→n or π*→π transitions . At present, it is still a challenge to illustrate the luminescence behaviors of the cooperatively CPs mixing two types of organic linkers. The emission band of 1-3 could be tentatively attributed to both a combination of the charge transfer process and intraligand π*→n or π*→π transition originating from different chromophores in the crystal structures as reported for d10 metal compounds with N-donor ligands  ( .

Spectroscopic characterizations of Cu(I)-2,2':5',4"-terpy complexes

Complexes 1-4 are insoluble in normal organic solvents. We are currently unable to obtain appropriate UV-VIS and 1H NMR spectra in solution. Alternatively, we have characterized spectroscopically complexes 1-4 by IR and UV-VIS measurements in the solid state. Complexes 1-4 showed the IR absorption bands for νC=C, νC=N, νC-C, νC-N stretching vibrations in the ranges of ca. 1600-1300cm-1 in  and . These IR absorption patterns were changed relative to those of metal-free 2,2':5',4"-terpy in  and , along with the strong absorption bands of 1060 (BF4), 840 (PF6), 844 (PF6) and 1363 (NO3) cm-1 for complexes 1-4, respectively.

Macrocycle structures have been obtained by assembling 4-dpds with several metal ions (e.g. Pt, Ir, Co, Ni) , but Ag(I)-based macrocycles are still less known. Interestingly, assembly between AgNO3 and 3-PPDS generated complex 1 containing 2:2 M:L macrocycle units, of which each Ag atom is five-coordinated by three O atoms from two NO3 - anions and two N atoms from two 3-PPDS ligands ( (a)). Both Ag-O and Ag-N bond lengths are within the normal range, and the C-S-S-C torsion angle (89.55°) is comparable to that of the free 3-PPDS ligand (81.33°) as expected . Moreover, the macrocycle cavity has its dimension of 7.34×13.01Å measured by Ag⋯Ag and S-S⋯S-S separations. As most examples in literatures , complex 1 also crystalizes in a non-chiral space group (P2/1) due to the presence of 1:1 macrocycle enantiomers.

Luminescent properties of complexes 1 and 2 

Solid state luminescent properties were examined for complexes 1 and 2 at room temperature (see ). Upon excitation at 300nm, complex 1 shows the maximal emission at 379nm, which is considered to be the result of the intraligand transition of 3-PPDS (λ em =383nm). Differently, complex 2 displays an intense emission with the maximum peak at 404nm with an evident red-shift compared with the 2-PPDS ligand (λ em =389nm). One probable reason for the lower energy emission of complex 2 may be ascribed to the presence of Ag-S bonding interactions, which is presumably originated from ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) or metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) .

UV-vis spectra

In the UV-vis spectra of the present complex in solid state, two absorption bands centered at 299 and 252nm were observed. The band at 299nm may be due to the metal to ligand charge transfer transition (MLCT). The band at 252nm may arise from the π-π transitions of the ligands. While in the UV-vis spectra in methanol, an absorption band at 306nm was observed, which may arise from the metal-to-ligand charge transfer transition (MLCT). The bands of 238, 285 and 294nm can be attributed to the π-π transitions of the ligands. This indicates that the structure of the title complex in solid state is quite different from that in methanol solution.

One-dimensional zigzag polymer {[HgI2(bpba)]⋅1.5CH3OH} n  (1) and binuclear metallamacrocycle [HgI2(bpit)]2 ⋅3H2O (2) were prepared based on linear and angular bipyridine ligands, respectively. Third-order nonlinear optical (NLO) properties of 1 and 2in DMF solution show that adducts 1 and 2 possess strong NLO self-focusing effect. The hyperpolarizability γ values of 1 and 2 are 2.10×10-29 and 3.24×10-29 esu, respectively. Abstract

Two bis(pyridyl) ligands: N,N'-bis(4-pyridyl)-1,4-benzenedicarboxamide (bpba) and N,N'-bis(3-pyridylformyl)imidazolidine-2-thione (bpit) have been designed and synthesized. Self-assembly of the linear ligand bpba and angular ligand bpit with HgI2 results in a one-dimensional zigzag polymer {[HgI2(bpba)]⋅1.5CH3OH} n  (1) and a binuclear metallamacrocycle [HgI2(bpit)]2 ⋅3H2O (2), respectively. Single crystal X-ray diffraction analyses reveal that in the crystal structure of 1 the linear ligand bpba is in transoid conformation, while in the crystal structure of 2 the angular ligand bpit coordinates with HgI2 in cisoid conformation, the different geometries of the two ligands attribute to forming the dissimilar frameworks of two HgI2 adducts. The determination of third-order nonlinear optical (NLO) properties of 1 and 2 in DMF solution shows that adducts 1 and 2 possess strong NLO self-focusing effect. The hyperpolarizability γ values of 1 and 2 are calculated to be 2.10×10-29 and 3.24×10-29 esu, respectively, which are comparable to those of some NLO materials. And the result indicates that the heavier atoms Hg and I together with the polymeric aggregation play an important role in determining their NLO properties.

Third-order nonlinear optical properties of adducts 1 and 2 

The UV-Visible spectra in DMF solution show that 1 and 2 display one strong absorption peak at 287 and 290nm, respectively, both of the two adducts have very low linear absorption ranging from 300 to 800nm. The absorptive bands could be attributed to the π-π* transitions of the ligands.

The NLO properties of 1 and 2 are investigated with 532nm laser pulse of 8ns duration in 5.89×10-4 moldm-3 for 1 and 4.92×10-4 moldm-3 for 2 in DMF solution.

Despite a similar chain linkage mode that is observed in 2, the symmetry character in crystal lattices of the two compounds is different. The asymmetric unit of 2 contains one and a half crystallographically unique Cu atoms, one hpdc3- anion, three coordinated ammonia molecules occupying four different lattice sites, a half of coordinated water molecule, and two independent half-occupied lattice water molecules. The Cu1 atom shows similar coordination environment and linkage to those in 1, but exhibits a distorted square-pyramidal geometry (τ=0.28), accompanied by a slight change in the N-Cu-O chelate bite angles (78.32° and 81.84°), and the dihedral angle between adjacent pyrimidine rings (72.87°) ( ). The Cu2 atom is located in a nearly perfect square-pyramidal geometry (τ=0.09), coordinated by four ammonia molecules in equatorial positions and one water molecule with longer bond directed toward the axial position (Fig. S1). The bridge modes of 1D polymer chain in 2 are identical to that in 1 but the nearest Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distance slightly extends to 6.06Å. Due to the existence of the cationic unit involving the Cu2 atom, [Cu(NH3)4(H2O)]2+, the 1D polymer chain built up by pentacoordinated Cu1 atom should be negatively charged in order to achieve charge balance within the whole crystal. In this case, it is considered that the hydrogen atom on the hydroxyl group of the H3hpdc molecule might be further removed to contribute an additional negative charge to chain-like polymer during the molecular assembly. Different from 1, in which the hydroxyl group associates with three carboxylate oxygen atoms of adjacent Hhpdc2- ligands through one lattice ammonia molecule based on hydrogen bonding interactions (the N⋅⋅⋅O distances: 2.79-2.88Å), no appropriate hydrogen bonding interaction (the N⋅⋅⋅O or O⋅⋅⋅O distances: <3.0Å) with the hydroxyl oxygen atom can be observed in 2. Furthermore, the IR spectrum (Fig. S2) of 2 exhibits an additional peak at about 1684cm-1, which is characteristic for the exocyclic carbonyl bond (CO) stretching vibration . Therefore, a carbonyl (oxo) tautomeric form is considered to exist predominantly in 2 after deprotonation of the hydroxyl group. This change in preference to the oxo tautomer should be beneficial to avoid this group to coordinate with the metal ion as the negative charge is delocalized over the nitrogen atom , and provide a precondition for forming similar topological linkage with different charge states.

The temperature dependence of the molar magnetic susceptibility of 1 with an applied field of 2kOe reveals that the χ  m  T value at 300K is 0.82cm3 Kmol-1 ( ), which is slightly larger than the calculated value of 0.75cm3 Kmol-1 for a non-coupled two-spin (S  1  = S  2  =1/2, g =2.0) system. As the temperature is lowered, the χ  m  T value decreases quickly and approaches zero at 2.0K. The fit of the experimental data to the Curie-Weiss law above 70K gives a Curie constant C =1.05cm3 Kmol-1 and a Weiss constant θ =-82.62K. The negative large θ value suggests the presence of strong antiferromagnetic exchange interactions between the Cu(II) ions. The temperature-dependence of the χ  m  T product of 2 was investigated in a magnetic field of 2kOe (). The observed χ  m  T value per Cu3 unit at 300K is 1.14cm3 Kmol-1, corresponding well to the expected spin-only value of 1.13cm3 Kmol-1 for three uncoupled Cu(II) ions with g =2. Upon further cooling, the χ  m  T value continuously decreases down to 0.08cm3 Kmol-1 at 2K. The Curie-Weiss fit to the magnetic susceptibility data above 40K gives a Curie constant of 1.31cm3 Kmol-1 and a Weiss constant of θ =-40.77K, indicating the presence of antiferromagnetic coupling interactions. Bearing in mind the structure of 1, the magnetic susceptibility data in the temperature range of 2-300K was fitted by Eq.  based on the modified Bonner and Fischer model  for 1D Heisenberg systems with J <0 with the Hamiltonian being H =-2J ∑  i  S  i  S  i +1   (1)    χ  m ( c h a i n )   = ( N  g 2   β 2  / k T ) ( 0.25 + 0.14995 x + 0.30094  x 2  ) / ( 1.0 + 1.9862 x + 0.68854  x 2  + 6.0626  x 3  )    where x =|J|/ kT, J is the exchange coupling constant between two nearest-neighbor spin doublets and other symbols have their usual meaning. The best-fitting parameters for compound 1 gave g =2.25, J =-28.38cm-1. Since compound 2 contained the [Cu2(hpdc)2(NH3)2]2- and [Cu(NH3)4(H2O)]2+ units, the χ  m  was divided into χ  m(chain)  and χ  Cu :  (2)    χ  m =    χ  m   c h a i n   +    χ Cu     where     χ  C u   = N  g 1 2   β 2  / 4 k T .

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis of the two compounds reveal that they are in the low-symmetry triclinic space group   P   1   ¯     and are of isostructural architecture. Thus, only the structure of complex 1 is described in details as the representation. As shown in  (a), the asymmetric unit of 1 consists of two crystallographic independent Eu3+ ions, three Ag+ ions, five IN- ligands, two μ3-OH, two     NO   3     -     ions as well as two water molecules. Both Eu(1) and Eu(2) are eight-coordinated, they employ distorted square antiprism coordination geometry accomplished by five carboxylate oxygen atoms from five IN- bridging ligands and three oxygen atoms from three μ3-OH ((b) and (c)). The Eu-O bond lengths range from 2.297(4) to 2.464(4)Å, the O-Eu-O bond angles vary from 66.3(9) to 153.0(1)°, which are in a reasonable scope compared with reported lanthanide complexes . In compound 1, there are three different coordination models for Ag(I). Ag(1) is coordinated in a linear fashion by two pyridyl nitrogen atoms of the IN- ligands. The N-Ag-N bond angle is 177.6(1)°; Ag(2) is surrounded by a N atom from IN- ligand and one O atom from     NO   3     -     with the N-Ag-O bond angle of 152.3(2)°; Ag(3) adopts trigonal geometry, coordinated by two N atoms from IN- ligands and one O atom from     NO   3     -    . The Ag-O bond lengths range from 2.400(8) to 2.566(1)Å and the Ag-N bond length varys from 2.138(6) to 2.375(4)Å. The N-Ag-N bond angles vary from 150.3(2)° to 177.6(2)°. All the bond lengths and angles are in agreement with the reported compounds .

Photoluminescence properties

The photoluminescent spectra of solid state samples 1 and 2 at room temperature are shown in  . The blue fluorescence for 2 can be observed, where the maximum emission wavelength is at 361nm. Correspondingly, the peak with the maximum excited light at ca. 340nm can be observed in the excitation spectra, which can boil down to ligand-ligand (IN-IN) interactions. The centroid distance between two interacting IN ligands is about 3.4556(82)Å. As known to all, the free HIN displays a feeble emission peak at 431nm while excited at 330nm in the ultraviolet (UV) region, so the fluorescence efficiency of 2 has been enhanced. We can attribute this to the IN- ligands' attachment with Ho(III) and Ag(I) ions which effectively increases the rigidity of the ligands and reduce the energy loss of radiation thermal vibration. The energy differences in Ag and Ho ions caused by the coordination environment make the blue shift of the emission from UV light to the blue color region. It's important to note that some reported articles show the emission spectrum of the Ag-Ag interaction  within 520-550nm. In addition, direct Ag-Ag interactions may be a very significant factor in the fluorescence properties of d10 metal coordination complexes . However, we do not observe emission peak of 2 at this range.

The detailed procedure of synthesis of complex 1, 2 and 3 were given in the ESI. The crystal structure of 1 is charactered by Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. And the complex 1 belongs to the monoclinic system C2/c space group. As shown in  , there are one Cd2+ ion, one L1, half a BDC2-, three coordinated water molecules, one free Br- anion, one free ethylalcohol and three free water molecules in the asymmetric unit. The central metal atom coordinates a deformed octahedral configuration with six atoms, in which including two different carboxylate oxygen atoms (Cd1-O4=2.303Å, Cd1-O9=2.354Å) donors from L1, one carboxylate oxygen donors (Cd1-O1=2.265Å) from BDC2- and three oxygen atoms (average Cd1-O=2.307Å) donors from three coordinated water molecules. Each L1 is connected to two adjacent Cd2+ ions to form a one-dimensional zig-zag linear chain. And each BDC2- is connected to the chain through adjacent Cd2+ ions to generate a one-dimensional trapezoidal double stranded structure, which can be extended indefinitely. From the b direction, it looks like a deformed s-shaped structure. In the direction of c, there are small pores (20.768×4.531Å2) on the microscopic surface.

The TG curve for 1 shows in Fig. S3, the thermal stability of complex 1 was conducted at a heating rate of 10°C/min from 25 to 850°C in a flowing atmosphere of nitrogen. The first stage of weight loss from 50 to 185°C corresponds to release of free water and free ethylalcohol (expt. 13.78%, calcd. 16.14%). Loss steps from 230 to 700°C are attributed to removal of L1 and BDC2-, which means collapse of the three-dimensional structure (expt. 67.17%, calcd. 66.88%). The complex 2 and 3 are in the same experiment condition. The first stage of weight loss from 32 to 140°C corresponds to release of free water and free ethylalcohol (expt. 12.83%, calcd. 17.37%). Loss steps from 230 to 800°C are attributed to removal of L2, which means collapse of the three-dimensional structure (expt. 57.63%, calcd. 66.66%). The reason why the experimental value is less than the calculated value is that the residue contains ZnO (2), CdO (3) and undecomposed carbon-containing compound. As shown in Fig. S2 and Fig. S5, we could conclude that the samples are good phase purity through the PXRD patterns for complex 1, 2 and 3.

Consulting the previous studies have shown that d10-CPs exhibit luminescent properties []. The emission spectrum of the free L1 exhibits two broad emission bands at 425nm and 475nm, besides, H2BDC exhibits a broad emission band at 385nm, which can be attributed to the ligand-centered electronic transition (LCET) ((a)). Similar to the free L1 and H2BDC, the complex 1 displayed two emission peaks at 365nm and 470nm. Compared with the free ligand, the 1 showed a weaker emission band blue-shifted to different extent, which probably originates from the ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT). The luminescence of 1 motivated us to investigate its potential application in the detection of small molecules, ions and anions. The luminescence spectra of the free L2 and the sample of complex 2 and 3 in solid state were investigated at room temperature under excitation at 300nm, respectively. The emission spectrum of the free L2 exhibits two broad emission bands at 425nm and 475nm, which can be attributed to the ligand-centered electronic transition (LCET) ((b)). The complex 2 and 3 displayed two emission peaks at 420nm and 460nm.

The luminescence of complex 1 inspires us to investigate its potential application for sensing different types of small molecules. The complex 1 samples were dispersed in common small organic molecule solvents which were DMF, H2O, DMSO, DMA, Pyridine, CH2Cl2, CH3CN, Ethylalcohol, Acetone, Ethylacetate, and NB. All sample concentration in different organic solvents is 1mM []. As depicted in  , different small organic molecule solvents can result in different effect on the fluorescence intensity of the dispersed solution of 1. As shown in (a) the luminescence intensity of organic solvent included samples largely depends on different solvents, and the maximum luminescent intensity decreases in the order EtOH>MeOH>Py>Acetone>DCM>DMSO>EtOAc>Water>DMA>DMF>MeCN>NB. Compound 1 displays the strongest emission in Ethylalcohol while shows nearly complete quenching effect in the NB suspension. This result indicates that compound 1 can be used as a fluorescent sensor for the selective detection of NB. For better understanding of the sensing ability of 1 towards NB, a series of suspensions of complex 1 with the gradual addition of analyte in the ethylalcohol system are prepared to record the emissive response []. Significant quenching was observed in (b), the luminescence intensity decreases clearly with the increasing NB concentration. When the concentration of NB in the complex 1 of ethanol suspension reaches 75.0μM, the fluorescence is almost completely quenched with a quench percentage of 87.4%. The fluorescence quenching of complex 1 were calculated by using the Stern-Volmer equation (I 0/I=1+K SV[M]), where I 0 represents the initial intensity of 1 in the absence of analyte, I is the emission intensity in the presence of analyte with molar concentration [M], and K SV is the quenching constant []. According to the quenching experimental data, the dose-response graph fitted the relationship I 0/I=0.4876e^([NB]/27.81)-0.6842 (R2=0.9976) in (c). Importantly, the S-V curves deviate from the straight line, and this phenomenon suggests that more than one quenching mechanism appear in the process, which can be attributed to the presence of simultaneous dynamic and static quenching []. We also researched the complex 2 and 3 for sensing these chemicals. They only can sense for NB, and the fluorescence quenching of 2 and 3 is less than 1 (Fig. S6). They cannot good enough to sense for these anions and ions.

Results and discussion

Synthesis and characterization

The direct reaction of oda in aqueous neutral solution with the stoichiometric amount of M(II) salts (M=Cu, Ni, Co, Mn, Ca, Mg) and Sm(III) led to the formation of complexes with formula [Sm2M3(oda)6]⋅x H2O (x =18 for M=Cu, Ni, Co, x =10 for Ca, and x =9 for M=Mn, Mg). This composition is supported by the elemental analysis and TGA determinations. Thermal analyses showed mass loss even at low temperatures as 50°C, suggesting the presence of weakly bonded water molecules. This characteristic is especially remarkable in compound 1, and seems to be responsible for the slight disagreement in the elemental analysis results. In fact, when solids are stored is a desiccator over silica, the TGA showed that, at least, two water molecules are not present anymore. For compounds 2, 3, and 4, the loss of mass involved a well defined two-steps process ( ). The first corresponds to crystallization water (12 molecules for 2 at 62°C, 12 molecules for 3 at 80°C, and 3 molecules for 4 at 100°C). The second loss of weight corresponds to coordinated water molecules (6 for complexes 2 - 4 at 202, 220, and 210°C, respectively). Hence, they can be formulated as [Sm2M3(oda)6(H2O)6]⋅x'H2O (x'=12 for M=Ni, Co, and x'=3 for M=Mn). The presence of six coordinated water molecules is also in agreement with the structure of 1, described in the next section. Only one process of loss of water can be observed for the other compounds, corresponding to all water molecules. At higher temperatures decomposition of the solid occurs.

Magnetic properties

The magnetic properties of compounds 1-4, in the form of χ MT vs. T (χ MT being the magnetic susceptibility per Sm2M3 unit), are shown in  . At room temperature, all of them present the expected values of χ MT for magnetically isolated paramagnetic ions, i.e., 2.0, 4.1, 10.0 and 13.0 cm3 mol-1 K, respectively. With the exception of 3 (Sm-Co complex), the χ MT values decrease linearly with T up to about 100K. Then, they decrease rapidly to get 0.75, 2.25, 4.6 and 11.2cm3 mol-1 K at 2K for 1-4, respectively.

Abstract

An uncommon copper(II) hydroxide layer-based coordination polymer [Cu3(OH)4(oba)] n  (1) (oba=4,4'-oxybisbenzoate) has been synthesized and tested as electro-catalyst for water oxidation under basic conditions. In comparison to classical Cu(OH)2, 1 exhibits improved thermal stability of up to ca. 350°C. Chronoamperometry studies indicate that catalyst 1 reaches an anodic current density of 0.1mAcm-2 at η=576mV; a TOF of 2×10-3s-1 at 418mV overpotential value. The catalyst 1 shows Faradaic efficiency of 95%. Long-term catalytic studies for 10h at a constant potential of 1.2V indicate that compound 1 is robust and retains its chemical composition. Infrared spectroscopy, powder X-ray diffraction analysis, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy and cyclic voltammetry studies of the pristine and post-catalytic compound 1-coated FTO electrodes further confirm that 1 retains its structural integrity throughout the catalytic cycle. Our results represent a proof-of-concept for designing next-generation robust and improved OER electrocatalysts based on earth-abundant metals.

Coordination polymers have captured great attention not only due to their structural fascination but potential applications in variety of fields i.e. heterogeneous catalysis , gas storage , magnetism  and luminescence  etc. Some CPs have also been proven to be good WOCs . Recently, Lin et al. have reported that a 4-(5-(pyridin-4-yl)-4H1,2,4-triazol-3-yl) benzoic acid-based Cu-MOF gives a current density of j=0.48mAcm-2 at+1.4V vs. SCE, an overpotential value of 780mV and turnover number (TON) of 2.25mol of O2 per mole of the catalyst. This catalyst also displayed 98% Faradaic efficiency . Ferdi et al. in 2016 have presented one-dimensional copper-based coordination polymer as a heterogeneous catalyst. This compound comprises Cu paddle-wheel units bridged via phosphine dioxide ligands. This catalyst offered a j value of 1mAcm-2 at η=563mV . A Cu-based MOF with 6,6'-dihydroxy-2,2'-bipy ligands showed a j of 0.16mAcm-2 at an η=640mV against NHE . In another study, the same Cu-polymer manifested an η=520mV for a j value of 0.80mAcm-2 under different experimental conditions .

For a comprehensive evaluation of the catalytic O2 evolution activity of compound 1, chronoamperometric studies were conducted at incremental potentials of 20mV. A plot of the logarithm of steady-state current densities versus overpotential gives a linear relationship in the range of 397-497mV ( ) with a Tafel slope value of 46.5mV dec-1. The catalyst offers a j of 1mAcm-2 at overpotential of 623mV whereas the equal current density can be achieved at η=644mV [Cu2-Po]n, , η=750mV [O2-CuCat] , η>600mV [Co/Fe Prussian blue catalyst] . The value of Tafel slope is also less than those reported for [Cu2-Po]n  , Cu-CO3  , O2-CuCat , and Cu-TEOA . A comparison of OER parameters for compound 1 with some previously reported Cu(II) compounds is provided in table SIT3.
