Conclusions

In summary, a novel, robust and an efficient coordination polymer containing Cu(II) ions coordinated by oxygen donor ligands, has been presented in the context of water oxidation catalysis. The chronoamperometric studies show that the catalyst requires overpotentials of 576 and 623mV to offer current densities of 0.1 and 1mAcm-2, respectively, at basic conditions. The catalyst shows a TOF of 2×10-3s-1 at overpotential of 418mV. Controlled potential electrolysis (CPE) shows that the catalyst exhibits a Faradaic efficiency of 95%. The catalyst preserved its chemical composition during 10h of bulk electrolysis which was confirmed by cyclic voltammetry, IR and powder X-ray diffraction studies of the catalyst before and after the catalytic process. This study demonstrates that copper-based metal-organic frameworks containing oxygen donor ligands are stable and efficient water oxidation electrocatalysts.

Abstract

A new chiral 3D covalent polymer based on chiral bridging ligands, the coordination environment around the CdII being pentagonal bipyramidal.

Abstract

A new chiral 3D metal-organic coordination polymer [Cd((S)-mal)] (mal=malic acid), has been solvothermally synthesized and characterized by elemental analysis, IR, TG and single crystal X-ray diffraction. Colorless crystals crystallize in the orthorhombic system, space group P212121, a =6.804(1), b =8.488(2), c =9.997(3)Å, V =577.35 (2)Å3, Z =4 and R 1 =0.0298. The structure of the compound exhibits a chiral 3D covalent framework based on chiral bridging ligands, the coordination environment around the CdII is pentagonal bipyramidal.

The TGA trace in   revealed that the decomposition takes place in one step. The slight decrease observed between 25 and 300°C can be assigned to the loss of some adsorbed water. Then, the steep weight loss between 340 and 400°C is associated to the decomposition of [Cd((S)-mal)]. It is worth noting that this decomposition occurs at quite high temperature and that the combustion of the hydrocarbon part of the compound is very exothermic, leading to an overflow of the temperature regulation. The final total weight loss of 43% corresponds well to the decomposition of [Cd((S)-mal)] into CdO (calc. 47.4%).

The infrared spectrum of [Cd((S)-mal)] recorded between 400 and 4000cm-1 confirms the structural analysis ( ). The absorptions at 2950 and 2930cm-1 correspond to the ν(CH) and ν(CH2) stretching modes. The absorption bands observed at 1560 and 1424cm-1 are assigned to the anti-symmetrical and symmetrical C-O vibrations, and the difference, Δν =136cm-1, is much smaller than that observed with the corresponding acid (Δν a =299cm-1) as expected for the observed coordination modes of the carboxylic groups . The absorption band for the C-O vibration of the alcoholic group of the malate ligands is observed at ca. 1114cm-1 and is much broader than observed in the first raw transition metal malates . It can be due to the peculiar multidentate coordination to the Cd atoms and also to the involvement of the alcoholic function in strong hydrogen bonding as denoted in  . Accordingly, a broad and intense band characteristic of the H-bonded OH is observed at 3265cm-1.

Catalytic properties

In order to probe the catalytic activity of the synthesized 1-D coordination polymer, the complex 1 was used as catalyst for aniline oxidation reaction under mild conditions (room temperature, atmospheric pressure and using H2O2 as oxidizing agent). Previously, the reaction was conducted without catalyst under the same conditions. No appreciable aniline conversion was detected in this case. However, by using the coordination polymer, it could be observed that the compound 1 was very active ( ), practically promoting the complete conversion of aniline (91.9%). Regarding the reaction selectivity, compound 1 preferentially catalyzed the formation of azobenzene (45.9% of selectivity), with some concomitant formation of nitrosobenzene, nitrobenzene and azoxybenzene as secondary products. The phenylhydroxylamine production was not detected. This result indicates that phenylhydroxylamine oxidizes to nitrosobenzene and further to nitrobenzene. In the course of the reaction, however, intermediate phenylhydroxylamine can react with aniline or nitrosobenzene to form azobenzene or azoxybenzene and the unconverted aniline can also react with nitrosobenzene by condensation to form azobenzene, which can also be oxidized to form azoxybenzene ( ) . In order to further examine the catalytic properties, we have investigated the conversion for the oxidation of aniline and the products selectivity, using only Cu(NO3)2 as catalyst under the same reaction conditions. The result showed that the Cu(NO3)2 led to a much lower aniline conversion (about 12%) relative to the compound 1. The Cu(NO3)2 catalyst displayed curious behavior in terms of selectivity, leading to the preferentially formation of N-phenylformamide (a product from the formylation of aniline) probably due to the acidity of the reaction medium, and only traces of nitrobenzene . The results highlight the superior catalytic performance of compound 1 for aniline oxidation to azobenzene compared with the Cu(NO3)2 salt.

We report the synthesis, crystal structures, magnetic properties, and thermal behavior of a family of isostructural transition metal gallate dihydrates containing infinite chains of trans-corner-sharing  M  O 6   octahedra. The gallates crystallize in the enantiomorphic space groups  P  3 1  21  and  P  3 2  21 , chirality being imparted by helical motifs in the structure. Ni(C7O5H4)⋅2H2O:  a = 8.824 ( 2 )   Å ,  c = 10.644 ( 2 )   Å ; Mn(C7O5H4)⋅2H2O:  a = 9.063 ( 2 )   Å ,  c = 10.947 ( 2 )   Å ; Co(C7O5H4)⋅2H2O:  a = 8.910 ( 2 )   Å ,  c = 10.887 ( 2 )   Å . The Co(II) and Ni(II) gallates exhibit antiferromagnetic behavior, with   T N  = 43  and 19 K, respectively, while Mn(II) gallate is paramagnetic down to 5 K. High-temperature X-ray powder diffraction indicates that crystallinity is lost near 200°C in all of the compounds. Decarboxylation of the gallate moieties is believed to facilitate this thermal decomposition.

Thermogravimetric curves for the gallates showed similar weight losses, but in different temperature ranges. Fe(III) gallate had the earliest weight loss, losing 68.0% of its total weight, mostly between 250 and 320°C. Mn(II) gallate lost 70.3%, but more gradually, with the major loss between 310 and 380°C. Ni(II) gallate similarly lost 72.5%, mostly between 320 and 390°C. Co(II) gallate had the latest and most gradual weight loss, losing 69.4% of its total weight, with the major loss between 310 and 415°C. Theoretical weight losses accompanying decomposition to binary oxides of the same valence are 69.2% for Fe(III), 72.6% for Mn(II), 71.6% for Ni(II), and 71.5% for Co(II). The formation of Fe2O3, MnO, NiO, and CoO is confirmed by peaks that appear in the high-temperature X-ray powder diffraction patterns above the temperatures of final mass loss. Very slight weight gains in Mn(II) and Co(II) gallates in the highest temperature range (above 450°C) presumably correspond to further oxidation of MnO and CoO to Mn2O3 and Co3O4, respectively. High-temperature powder diffraction indicates that crystallinity is lost much earlier than the major TGA weight losses: below 150°C for Fe(III) gallate, around 200°C for Co(II) and Mn(II) gallate, and slightly above 200°C for Ni (II) gallate.

Magnetic susceptibility data were obtained for the powders of all four compounds. Zero-field-cooled data did not differ significantly from field-cooled data. From the slopes of the  1 / χ  plots ( ) in their high-temperature linear regimes, the magnetic moments per metal ion were found to be 5.69 BM for Mn(II) gallate, 6.49 BM for Fe(III) gallate, 4.89 BM for Co(II) gallate, and 3.22 BM for Ni(II) gallate, in reasonable agreement with expectations for these ions in octahedral coordination with oxygen. The Curie-Weiss temperatures, Θ, are -354.5 K for Fe(III) gallate, -29.5 K for Ni(II) gallate, -52.0 K for Co(II) gallate, and -41.5 K for Mn(II) gallate. We ascribe the higher value for the iron compound to the higher charge of Fe(III) compared with the M(II) phases. Co(II) and Ni(II) gallates exhibit peaks in susceptibility at 43 K and 19 K, respectively, indicating antiferromagnetic (AF) behavior below these temperatures. The high   T N   and strong AF ordering of the Co(II) phase suggest that its M O M angle may be at the high end of our estimated range, closer to linearity. Conversely, the absence of AF order for the Mn(II) phase may stem from its more acute M O M angle. Analogous, but more linear, antiferromagnetic chains of trans-corner-sharing metal octahedra are found in Rb2FeF5 and its hydrates. Studies of these compounds  reported antiferromagnetic behavior qualitatively similar to that of the Ni(II) and Co(II) gallates.

Zn2(NCS)2L2  

The complex Zn2(NCS)2L2  crystallises in the monoclinic P21 space group with one molecule in the asymmetric part of the unit cell. From the view along the x direction ( a) it is seen that all the (SCN)- ligands are directed in the same direction, i.e., towards the Schiff base fragment. This apparently helps to pack the molecules efficiently in the crystal lattice. Molecules lay along the y axis and are related by a 21 screw axis. Such a molecular arrangement results in a number of short contacts between the (SCN)- ligand and the hydrogen atoms from the Schiff base fragment. Also some short C-H…C interactions between the neighbouring Schiff base fragments can be observed ( a and ). No π…π stacking appears in this structure. All the sulfur atoms are relatively far from the zinc atoms (ca. 5Å) and they do not belong to the coordination sphere of the Zn(II) centre.

Cd2(NCS)2L2  

This complex crystallises in the monoclinic P21/n space group with one independent molecule in the asymmetric part of the unit cell. The molecular arrangement in the crystal lattice is slightly similar to the one in the complex Zn2(NCS)2L2 : the (SCN)- ligands are all directed in the same direction - towards the Schiff base fragments (see  a), thus forming an infinite ribbon in the crystal lattice. Also the shortest intermolecular contacts are present between (SCN)- and the hydrogen atoms from the Schiff base (see b and ). However, in this case, the distance between one of the sulfur atoms from (SCN)- and the closest cadmium atom from the neighbouring molecule is equal only to 2.684Å. As a consequence, the sulfur atom is also coordinated by Cd(II). The coordination of the two cadmium cations in this molecule is different. No π…π stacking appears in this structure. In the z direction some empty channels are observed in the 3D structure of the Cd2(NCS)2L2  complex (see  b). The size of the channel is ca. 3.4×5.5Å when only heavy atoms are considered (see Fig. 2a in the Supporting material). When the hydrogen atoms are also taken into account, it turns out that the distances between the closest hydrogen atoms from the methyl groups are close to 2.610 and 2.849Å (see Fig. 2b in the Supporting materials). As a consequence, the channels are too narrow to host any solvent molecules.

A new co-ordination framework {[Zn(Ac)2(bbbm)](CH3OH)2} n  has been prepared and characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction and Z-scan technique. The polymer has a helical chain structure formed by bbbm linking two adjacent Zn(II) ions and exhibits strong NLO refraction property with n 2 value of 1.38×10-17 m2 W-1, which can match those of the best known third-order NLO materials such as inorganic oxides, semiconductors, and cluster compounds.

Abstract

A new co-ordination framework {[Zn(Ac)2(bbbm)](CH3OH)2} n  (1) (bbbm=1,1'-(1,4-butanediyl)bis-1H-benzimidazole) has been synthesized and structurally characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction and Z-scan technique. The polymer has a one-dimensional single helical chain structure formed by bbbm linking two adjacent Zn(II) ions and exhibits strong NLO refraction property with n 2 value of 1.38×10-17 m2 W-1, which can match those of the best known third-order NLO materials such as inorganic oxides, semiconductors, and cluster compounds.

The NLO property of 1 is measured in a 1.7×10-4 moldm-3 DMF solution by Z-scan technique. 3 The NLO properties were measured with a linearly polarized laser light (λ=532 nm; pulse widths=7 ns) generated from a Q-switched and frequency-doubled Nd:YAG laser. An aperture of 0.5 mm in radius was placed in front of the detector to assist the measurement of the self-focusing effect.   It exhibits weak NLO absorptive and strong NLO refractive properties.

depicts NLO refractive property of polymer 1. A reasonably good fit between the experimental data (black dot) and the theoretical curves (solids curves) based on Eqs.  was obtained. The refractive index n 2 was calculated to be 1.38×10-17 m2 W-1, which shows that the polymer has a positive sign for the refractive nonlinearity. The valley/peak pattern of the normalized transmittance curve shows characteristic self-focusing behavior. The n 2 is better than some best performing NLO materials such as inorganic oxides like SiO2 (n 2=2×10-20 m2 W-1), semiconductors like CdS (n 2=2.5×10-18 m2 W-1), and organic polymers like DANS (n 2=8×10-18 m2 W-1) . It is obvious that polymer 1 exhibits stronger NLO refractive effect, which can match those of the best-known third-order NLO materials in neat solid form. Moreover, its n 2 value is also comparable to those of cluster compounds like [W2Ag4S8(AsPh3)4] (n 2=5.9×10-16 m2 W-1) , {[Et4N]2[MoS4Cu4(CN)4]} n  (n 2=1.8×10-16 m2 W-1)  and our reported coordination polymers like [Zn(bbbt)(NCS)2] n  (n 2=4.53×10-18 m2 W-1), [Cd(bbbt)2(NCS)2] n  (n 2=3.07×10-19 m2 W-1) and [Zn(pbbt)(NCS)2] n  (n 2=3.02×10-18 m2 W-1).
